\hypertarget{chapter-2-the-categorical-substrate}{%
\chapter{Chapter 2: The Categorical
Substrate}\label{chapter-2-the-categorical-substrate}}

\hypertarget{higher-categorical-foundations}{%
\section{Higher-Categorical
Foundations}\label{higher-categorical-foundations}}

We work in the framework of \textbf{Higher Topos Theory} and
\textbf{Homotopy Type Theory (HoTT)}, which provides a foundation where
equality is replaced by paths, propositions are types, and proofs are
witnesses \autocite{HoTTBook,Lurie09,Shulman18}. This framework is
strictly more expressive than ZFC set theory and naturally encodes the
homotopical structure of configuration spaces.

\begin{definition}[Ambient $\infty$-Topos]
Let $\mathcal{E}$ be a \textbf{cohesive $(\infty, 1)$-topos} in the sense of Schreiber [@Schreiber13], equipped with the shape/flat/sharp modality adjunction:
$$
\Pi \dashv \flat \dashv \sharp : \mathcal{E} \to \infty\text{-Grpd}
$$
The cohesion structure provides:
\begin{itemize}
    \item \textbf{Shape} $\Pi$: Extracts the underlying homotopy type (fundamental $\infty$-groupoid)
    \item \textbf{Flat} $\flat$: Includes discrete $\infty$-groupoids as ``constant'' objects
    \item \textbf{Sharp} $\sharp$: Includes codiscrete objects (contractible path spaces)
\end{itemize}
\end{definition}

Standard examples include the topos of smooth \(\infty\)-stacks
\(\mathbf{Sh}_\infty(\mathbf{CartSp})\) and the topos of differential
cohesive types.

\begin{definition}[Category of spatial types]
Let $\mathbf{Type}_{\mathcal{E}}$ denote the category of types in $\mathcal{E}$. Objects are \textbf{spatial types} ($\infty$-sheaves on the site of smooth manifolds) and morphisms are \textbf{transport functors}---maps that respect the path structure. This generalizes the category $\mathbf{Pol}$ of Polish spaces: every Polish space embeds as a 0-truncated spatial type via its underlying set, but $\mathbf{Type}_{\mathcal{E}}$ additionally contains:
\begin{itemize}
    \item \textbf{Higher groupoids}: Types with non-trivial $\pi_n$ for $n \geq 1$
    \item \textbf{Stacks}: Types with automorphisms (gauge symmetries)
    \item \textbf{Moduli spaces}: Types parametrizing families of structures
\end{itemize}
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Categorical Hypostructure]
Let $\mathcal{E}$ be a cohesive $(\infty, 1)$-topos. A \textbf{Hypostructure} is a tuple $\mathbb{H} = (\mathcal{X}, \nabla, \Phi_\bullet, \tau)$ where:
\begin{enumerate}
    \item \textbf{State Object} $\mathcal{X} \in \text{Obj}(\mathcal{E})$: The \textbf{configuration stack} representing all possible states. This is an $\infty$-sheaf encoding both the state space and its symmetries. The homotopy groups $\pi_n(\mathcal{X})$ capture:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item $\pi_0$: Connected components (topological sectors)
        \item $\pi_1$: Gauge symmetries and monodromy
        \item $\pi_n$ ($n \geq 2$): Higher coherences and anomalies
    \end{itemize}
    \item \textbf{Flat Connection} $\nabla: \mathcal{X} \to T\mathcal{X}$: A section of the tangent $\infty$-bundle, encoding the dynamics as \textbf{parallel transport}. The semiflow $S_t$ is recovered as the exponential map:
    $$S_t = \exp(t \cdot \nabla): \mathcal{X} \to \mathcal{X}$$
    The flatness condition $[\nabla, \nabla] = 0$ ensures consistency of time evolution.
    \item \textbf{Cohomological Height} $\Phi_\bullet: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}_\infty$: A \textbf{cohomological field theory} assigning to each state its energy/complexity. Here $\mathbb{R}_\infty$ is the real line viewed as an $\infty$-groupoid (with only identity paths). The notation $\Phi_\bullet$ indicates this is a \textbf{derived functor}---it comes equipped with higher coherences $\Phi_n$ for all $n$.
    \item \textbf{Truncation Structure} $\tau = (\tau_C, \tau_D, \tau_{SC}, \tau_{LS})$: The axioms (C, D, SC, LS, Cap, TB, GC) are realized as \textbf{truncation functors} on the homotopy groups of $\mathcal{X}$:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item \textbf{Axiom C (Compactness)}: $\tau_C$ truncates unbounded orbits: $\|\pi_0(\mathcal{O}_x)\| < \infty$
        \item \textbf{Axiom D (Dissipation)}: $\tau_D$ bounds the energy filtration: $\Phi_\bullet$ is bounded above
        \item \textbf{Axiom SC (Scaling)}: $\tau_{SC}$ constrains weight gradings: scaling exponents satisfy $\alpha \leq \beta$
        \item \textbf{Axiom LS (Stiffness)}: $\tau_{LS}$ truncates unstable modes: $\pi_k(\mathcal{X}|_{\text{unstable}}) = 0$ for $k \geq k_0$
    \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

\textbf{Remark 2.2.1 (Classical Recovery).} When
\(\mathcal{E} = \mathbf{Set}\) (the trivial topos), Definition 2.2
reduces to classical structural flow data: \(\mathcal{X}\) becomes a
Polish space \(X\) (a 0-truncated spatial type), the connection
\(\nabla\) becomes a vector field generating a semiflow, and the
truncation functors become 0-truncated type checks (decidable
propositions).

\textbf{Remark 2.2.2 (Homotopical Advantage).} The
\(\infty\)-categorical formulation provides: - \textbf{Robustness to
deformation}: Two states \(x, y\) with
\(\text{Path}_{\mathcal{X}}(x, y) \neq \emptyset\) are ``equivalent''
for regularity purposes - \textbf{Natural gauge handling}: Symmetries
are encoded in \(\pi_1(\mathcal{X})\), not imposed externally -
\textbf{Obstruction theory}: Singularities are detected as non-trivial
cohomology classes, not analytic blow-up

\begin{definition}[Structural flow data—Classical presentation]
For computational purposes, a Hypostructure $\mathbb{H}$ admits a \textbf{classical presentation} as a tuple:
$$
\mathcal{S} = (X, d, \mathcal{B}, \mu, (S_t)_{t \in T}, \Phi, \mathfrak{D})
$$
where:
\end{definition}

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \((X, d)\) is a Polish space with metric \(d\), viewed as the
  0-truncation \(\tau_{\leq 0}(\mathcal{X})\). We adopt the viewpoint of
  \textbf{Metric Geometry} as systematized by \textbf{Burago, Burago,
  and Ivanov \autocite{Burago01}},
\item
  \(\mathcal{B}\) is the Borel \(\sigma\)-algebra on \(X\),
\item
  \(\mu\) is a \(\sigma\)-finite Borel measure on \((X, \mathcal{B})\),
\item
  \(T \in \{\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}, \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}\}\) is the time
  monoid,
\item
  \((S_t)_{t \in T}\) is the semiflow induced by
  \(\exp(t \cdot \nabla)\) (Definition 2.5),
\item
  \(\Phi: X \to [0, \infty]\) is the height functional \(\Phi_0\)
  (Definition 2.9),
\item
  \(\mathfrak{D}: X \to [0, \infty]\) is the dissipation functional
  (Definition 2.12).
\end{itemize}

\begin{definition}[Morphisms of structural flows]
A morphism $f: \mathcal{S}_1 \to \mathcal{S}_2$ between structural flow data is a continuous map $f: X_1 \to X_2$ such that:
\end{definition}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \(f\) is equivariant: \(f \circ S^1_t = S^2_t \circ f\) for all
  \(t \in T\),
\item
  \(f\) is height-nonincreasing: \(\Phi_2(f(x)) \leq \Phi_1(x)\) for all
  \(x \in X_1\),
\item
  \(f\) is dissipation-compatible:
  \(\mathfrak{D}_2(f(x)) \leq C_f \mathfrak{D}_1(x)\) for some constant
  \(C_f \geq 1\).
\end{enumerate}

This defines the category \(\mathbf{StrFlow}\) of structural flows. This
trajectory-centric formulation aligns with the \textbf{Behavioral
Approach} of Willems \autocite{Willems91}, where a dynamical system is
defined not by input-output maps but by the kernel of admissible
behaviors in the signal space.

\begin{definition}[Forgetful functor]
There is a forgetful functor $U: \mathbf{StrFlow} \to \mathbf{DynSys}$ to the category of topological dynamical systems, given by $U(\mathcal{S}) = (X, (S_t)_{t \in T})$. This categorical formulation draws upon Lawvere's Functorial Semantics [@Lawvere63], viewing dynamical theories as categories and models as functors.
\end{definition}

\hypertarget{state-spaces-and-regularity}{%
\section{State spaces and
regularity}\label{state-spaces-and-regularity}}

\begin{definition}[Semiflow]
A \textbf{semiflow} (parallel transport along a flat connection) on a Polish space $X$ is a family of maps $(S_t: X \to X)_{t \in T}$ satisfying:
\end{definition}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Identity:} \(S_0 = \mathrm{Id}_X\),
\item
  \textbf{Semigroup property:} \(S_{t+s} = S_t \circ S_s\) for all
  \(t, s \in T\),
\item
  \textbf{Continuity:} The map \((t, x) \mapsto S_t x\) is continuous on
  \(T \times X\).
\end{enumerate}

When \(T = \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}\), we speak of a continuous-time
semiflow; when \(T = \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}\), a discrete-time semiflow.

\begin{definition}[Maximal semiflow]
A \textbf{maximal semiflow} allows trajectories to be defined only on a maximal interval. For each $x \in X$, we define the \textbf{blow-up time}
$$
T_*(x) := \sup\{T > 0 : t \mapsto S_t x \text{ is defined and continuous on } [0, T)\} \in (0, \infty].
$$
The trajectory $t \mapsto S_t x$ is defined for $t \in [0, T_*(x))$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Stochastic extension]
In the stochastic setting, we replace the semiflow by a \textbf{Markov semigroup} $(P_t)_{t \geq 0}$ acting on the space $\mathcal{P}(X)$ of Borel probability measures on $X$:
$$
(P_t \nu)(A) = \int_X p_t(x, A) \, d\nu(x),
$$
where $p_t(x, \cdot)$ is a transition kernel. The height functional is extended to measures by
$$
\Phi(\nu) := \int_X \Phi(x) \, d\nu(x),
$$
and similarly for dissipation.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Generalized semiflow]
For systems with non-unique solutions (e.g., weak solutions of PDEs), we define a \textbf{generalized semiflow} as a set-valued map $S_t: X \rightrightarrows X$ such that:
\end{definition}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \(S_0(x) = \{x\}\) for all \(x\),
\item
  \(S_{t+s}(x) \subseteq S_t(S_s(x)) := \bigcup_{y \in S_s(x)} S_t(y)\)
  for all \(t, s \geq 0\),
\item
  The graph \(\{(t, x, y) : y \in S_t(x)\}\) is closed in
  \(T \times X \times X\).
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{height-functionals}{%
\section{Height functionals}\label{height-functionals}}

\begin{definition}[Height functional]
A \textbf{height functional} on a structural flow is a function $\Phi: X \to [0, \infty]$ satisfying:
\end{definition}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Lower semicontinuity:} \(\Phi\) is lower semicontinuous, i.e.,
  \(\{x : \Phi(x) \leq E\}\) is closed for all \(E \geq 0\),
\item
  \textbf{Non-triviality:} \(\{x : \Phi(x) < \infty\}\) is nonempty,
\item
  \textbf{Properness:} For each \(E < \infty\), the sublevel set
  \(K_E := \{x \in X : \Phi(x) \leq E\}\) has compact closure in \(X\).
\end{enumerate}

\begin{definition}[Coercivity]
The height functional $\Phi$ is \textbf{coercive} if for every sequence $(x_n) \subset X$ with $d(x_n, x_0) \to \infty$ for some fixed $x_0 \in X$, we have $\Phi(x_n) \to \infty$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Lyapunov candidate]
We say $\Phi$ is a \textbf{Lyapunov candidate} if there exists $C \geq 0$ such that for all trajectories $u(t) = S_t x$:
$$
\Phi(u(t)) \leq \Phi(u(s)) + C(t - s) \quad \text{for all } 0 \leq s \leq t < T_*(x).
$$
When $C = 0$, $\Phi$ is a \textbf{Lyapunov functional}.
\end{definition}

\hypertarget{dissipation-structure}{%
\section{Dissipation structure}\label{dissipation-structure}}

\begin{definition}[Dissipation functional]
A \textbf{dissipation functional} is a measurable function $\mathfrak{D}: X \to [0, \infty]$ that quantifies the instantaneous rate of irreversible cost along trajectories.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Dissipation measure]
Along a trajectory $u: [0, T) \to X$, the \textbf{dissipation measure} is the Radon measure on $[0, T)$ given by the Lebesgue–Stieltjes decomposition:
$$
d\mathcal{D}_u = \mathfrak{D}(u(t)) \, dt + d\mathcal{D}_u^{\mathrm{sing}},
$$
where $\mathfrak{D}(u(t)) \, dt$ is the absolutely continuous part and $d\mathcal{D}_u^{\mathrm{sing}}$ is the singular part (supported on a set of Lebesgue measure zero).
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Total cost]
The \textbf{total cost} of a trajectory on $[0, T]$ is
$$
\mathcal{C}_T(x) := \int_0^T \mathfrak{D}(S_t x) \, dt.
$$
For the full trajectory up to blow-up time:
$$
\mathcal{C}_*(x) := \mathcal{C}_{T_*(x)}(x) = \int_0^{T_*(x)} \mathfrak{D}(S_t x) \, dt.
$$
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Energy–dissipation inequality]
The pair $(\Phi, \mathfrak{D})$ satisfies an \textbf{energy–dissipation inequality} if there exist constants $\alpha > 0$ and $C \geq 0$ such that for all trajectories $u(t) = S_t x$:
$$
\Phi(u(t_2)) + \alpha \int_{t_1}^{t_2} \mathfrak{D}(u(s)) \, ds \leq \Phi(u(t_1)) + C(t_2 - t_1)
$$
for all $0 \leq t_1 \leq t_2 < T_*(x)$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Energy–dissipation identity]
When equality holds and $C = 0$:
$$
\Phi(u(t_2)) + \alpha \int_{t_1}^{t_2} \mathfrak{D}(u(s)) \, ds = \Phi(u(t_1)),
$$
we say the system satisfies an \textbf{energy–dissipation identity} (balance law).
\end{definition}

\hypertarget{bornological-and-uniform-structures}{%
\section{Bornological and uniform
structures}\label{bornological-and-uniform-structures}}

\begin{definition}[Bornology]
A \textbf{bornology} on $X$ is a collection $\mathcal{B}$ of subsets of $X$ (called bounded sets) such that:
\end{definition}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \(\mathcal{B}\) covers \(X\): \(\bigcup_{B \in \mathcal{B}} B = X\),
\item
  \(\mathcal{B}\) is hereditary: if \(A \subseteq B \in \mathcal{B}\),
  then \(A \in \mathcal{B}\),
\item
  \(\mathcal{B}\) is stable under finite unions.
\end{enumerate}

The bornology induced by \(\Phi\) is
\(\mathcal{B}_\Phi := \{B \subseteq X : \sup_{x \in B} \Phi(x) < \infty\}\).

\begin{definition}[Equicontinuity]
The semiflow $(S_t)$ is \textbf{equicontinuous on bounded sets} if for every $B \in \mathcal{B}_\Phi$ and every $\varepsilon > 0$, there exists $\delta > 0$ such that for all $t \in [0, 1]$:
$$
x, y \in B, \, d(x, y) < \delta \implies d(S_t x, S_t y) < \varepsilon.
$$
\end{definition}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{normalization-and-gauge-structure}{%
\section{2.4 Normalization and Gauge
Structure}\label{normalization-and-gauge-structure}}

\hypertarget{symmetry-groups}{%
\section{Symmetry groups}\label{symmetry-groups}}

\begin{definition}[Symmetry group action]
Let $G$ be a locally compact Hausdorff topological group. A \textbf{continuous action} of $G$ on $X$ is a continuous map $G \times X \to X$, $(g, x) \mapsto g \cdot x$, such that:
\end{definition}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \(e \cdot x = x\) for all \(x \in X\) (where \(e\) is the identity),
\item
  \((gh) \cdot x = g \cdot (h \cdot x)\) for all \(g, h \in G\),
  \(x \in X\).
\end{enumerate}

\begin{definition}[Isometric action]
The action is \textbf{isometric} if $d(g \cdot x, g \cdot y) = d(x, y)$ for all $g \in G$, $x, y \in X$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Proper action]
The action is \textbf{proper} if for every compact $K \subseteq X$, the set $\{g \in G : g \cdot K \cap K \neq \emptyset\}$ is compact in $G$.
\end{definition}

\textbf{Example 5.4 (Common symmetry groups).}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Translations:} \(G = \mathbb{R}^n\) acting by
  \((a, u) \mapsto u(\cdot - a)\) on function spaces.
\item
  \textbf{Rotations:} \(G = SO(n)\) acting by
  \((R, u) \mapsto u(R^{-1} \cdot)\).
\item
  \textbf{Scalings:} \(G = \mathbb{R}_{> 0}\) acting by
  \((\lambda, u) \mapsto \lambda^\alpha u(\lambda \cdot)\) for some
  \(\alpha\).
\item
  \textbf{Parabolic rescaling:} \(G = \mathbb{R}_{> 0}\) acting by
  \((\lambda, u) \mapsto \lambda^\alpha u(\lambda \cdot, \lambda^2 \cdot)\).
\item
  \textbf{Gauge transformations:} \(G = \mathcal{G}\) (a gauge group)
  acting by \((g, A) \mapsto g^{-1} A g + g^{-1} dg\).
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{gauge-maps-and-normalized-slices}{%
\section{Gauge maps and normalized
slices}\label{gauge-maps-and-normalized-slices}}

\begin{definition}[Gauge map]
A \textbf{gauge map} is a measurable function $\Gamma: X \to G$ such that the \textbf{normalized state}
$$
\tilde{x} := \Gamma(x) \cdot x
$$
lies in a designated \textbf{normalized slice} $\Sigma \subseteq X$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Normalized slice]
A \textbf{normalized slice} is a measurable subset $\Sigma \subseteq X$ such that:
\end{definition}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Transversality:} For \(\mu\)-almost every \(x \in X\), the
  orbit \(G \cdot x\) intersects \(\Sigma\).
\item
  \textbf{Uniqueness (up to discrete ambiguity):} For each orbit
  \(G \cdot x\), the intersection \(G \cdot x \cap \Sigma\) is a
  discrete (possibly singleton) set.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{proposition}[Existence of gauge maps]
Suppose the action of $G$ on $X$ is proper and isometric. Then for any normalized slice $\Sigma$, there exists a measurable gauge map $\Gamma: X \to G$.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
For each $x \in X$, let $\pi(x) \in \Sigma$ be a point in $G \cdot x \cap \Sigma$ (using the axiom of choice, or constructively via a measurable selection theorem since the action is proper). Define $\Gamma(x)$ to be any $g \in G$ such that $g \cdot x = \pi(x)$. The properness of the action ensures this is well-defined and measurable.
\end{proof}

\begin{definition}[Bounded gauge]
The gauge map $\Gamma$ is \textbf{bounded on energy sublevels} if for each $E < \infty$, there exists a compact set $K_G \subseteq G$ such that $\Gamma(x) \in K_G$ for all $x \in K_E$.
\end{definition}

\hypertarget{normalized-functionals}{%
\section{Normalized functionals}\label{normalized-functionals}}

\begin{definition}[Normalized height and dissipation]
The \textbf{normalized height} and \textbf{normalized dissipation} are
$$
\tilde{\Phi}(x) := \Phi(\Gamma(x) \cdot x), \qquad \tilde{\mathfrak{D}}(x) := \mathfrak{D}(\Gamma(x) \cdot x).
$$
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Normalized trajectory]
For a trajectory $u(t) = S_t x$, the \textbf{normalized trajectory} is
$$
\tilde{u}(t) := \Gamma(u(t)) \cdot u(t).
$$
\end{definition}

\begin{axiom}[N (Normalization compatibility along trajectories)]
Along any trajectory $u(t) = S_t x$ with bounded energy $\sup_t \Phi(u(t)) \leq E$, the normalized functionals are comparable to the original functionals: there exist constants $0 < c_1(E) \leq c_2(E) < \infty$ (possibly depending on the energy level) such that:
$$
c_1(E) \Phi(y) \leq \tilde{\Phi}(y) \leq c_2(E) \Phi(y), \qquad c_1(E) \mathfrak{D}(y) \leq \tilde{\mathfrak{D}}(y) \leq c_2(E) \mathfrak{D}(y)
$$
for all $y$ on the trajectory.
\end{axiom}

\textbf{Fallback.} When Axiom N degenerates (i.e., \(c_1(E) \to 0\) or
\(c_2(E) \to \infty\) as \(E \to \infty\)), one works in unnormalized
coordinates. The theorems requiring normalization (Theorem 6.2) apply
only where N holds with controlled constants.

\hypertarget{generic-normalization-as-derived-property}{%
\section{Generic normalization as derived
property}\label{generic-normalization-as-derived-property}}

With Scaling Structure (Axiom SC, defined below) in place, Generic
Normalization becomes a derived consequence rather than an independent
axiom.

\begin{definition}[Scaling subgroup]
A \textbf{scaling subgroup} is a one-parameter subgroup $(\mathcal{S}_\lambda)_{\lambda > 0} \subset G$ of the symmetry group, with $\mathcal{S}_1 = e$ and $\mathcal{S}_\lambda \circ \mathcal{S}_\mu = \mathcal{S}_{\lambda\mu}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Scaling exponents]
The \textbf{scaling exponents} along an orbit where $(\mathcal{S}_\lambda)$ acts are constants $\alpha > 0$ and $\beta > 0$ such that:
\end{definition}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Dissipation scaling:} There exists \(C_\alpha \geq 1\) such
  that for all \(x\) on the orbit and \(\lambda > 0\): \[
  C_\alpha^{-1} \lambda^\alpha \mathfrak{D}(x) \leq \mathfrak{D}(\mathcal{S}_\lambda \cdot x) \leq C_\alpha \lambda^\alpha \mathfrak{D}(x).
  \]
\item
  \textbf{Temporal scaling:} Under the rescaling
  \(s = \lambda^\beta (T - t)\) near a reference time \(T\), the time
  differential transforms as \(dt = \lambda^{-\beta} ds\).
\end{enumerate}

\begin{axiom}[SC (Scaling Structure on orbits)]
On any orbit where the scaling subgroup $(\mathcal{S}_\lambda)_{\lambda > 0}$ acts with well-defined scaling exponents $(\alpha, \beta)$, the \textbf{subcritical dissipation condition} holds:
$$
\alpha > \beta.
$$
\end{axiom}

\textbf{Fallback (Mode S.E).} When Axiom SC fails along a
trajectory---either because no scaling subgroup acts, or the subcritical
condition \(\alpha > \beta\) is violated---the trajectory may exhibit
\textbf{supercritical symmetry cascade} (Resolution mode 3, Theorem
6.1). Property GN is not derived in this case; Type II blow-up must be
excluded by other means or accepted as a possible failure mode.

\begin{definition}[Supercritical sequence]
A sequence $(\lambda_n) \subset \mathbb{R}_{> 0}$ is \textbf{supercritical} if $\lambda_n \to \infty$.
\end{definition}

\textbf{Remark 5.14.} The exponent \(\alpha\) measures how strongly
dissipation responds to zooming; \(\beta\) measures how remaining time
compresses under scaling. The condition \(\alpha > \beta\) ensures that
supercritical rescaling amplifies dissipation faster than it compresses
time, making infinite-cost profiles unavoidable in the limit.

\textbf{Remark 5.15 (Scaling structure is soft).} For most systems of
interest, the scaling structure is immediate from dimensional analysis:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  For parabolic PDEs with scaling
  \((x, t) \mapsto (\lambda x, \lambda^2 t)\), the exponents follow from
  computing how \(\mathfrak{D}\) and \(\mathrm{d}t\) transform.
\item
  For kinetic systems, the scaling comes from velocity-space rescaling.
\item
  For discrete systems, the scaling may be combinatorial (e.g., term
  depth).
\item
  For systems without natural scaling symmetry, SC does not apply and GN
  must be established by other structural means.
\end{itemize}

No hard analysis is required to identify SC where it applies; it is a
purely structural/dimensional property.

\begin{definition}[Scale parameter]
A \textbf{scale parameter} is a continuous function $\sigma: G \to \mathbb{R}_{> 0}$ such that $\sigma(e) = 1$ and $\sigma(gh) = \sigma(g) \sigma(h)$ (i.e., $\sigma$ is a group homomorphism to $(\mathbb{R}_{> 0}, \times)$). For the scaling subgroup, $\sigma(\mathcal{S}_\lambda) = \lambda$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Supercritical rescaling]
A sequence $(g_n) \subset G$ is \textbf{supercritical} if $\sigma(g_n) \to 0$ or $\sigma(g_n) \to \infty$ (depending on convention: the scale escapes the critical regime).
\end{definition}

\textbf{Property GN (Generic Normalization).} For any trajectory
\(u(t) = S_t x\) with finite total cost \(\mathcal{C}_*(x) < \infty\),
if:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \((t_n)\) is a sequence with \(t_n \nearrow T_*(x)\),
\item
  \((g_n) \subset G\) is a supercritical sequence,
\item
  the rescaled states \(v_n := g_n \cdot u(t_n)\) converge to a limit
  \(v_\infty \in X\),
\end{itemize}

then the normalized dissipation integral along any trajectory through
\(v_\infty\) must diverge: \[
\int_0^\infty \tilde{\mathfrak{D}}(S_t v_\infty) \, dt = \infty.
\]

\textbf{Remark 5.18.} Property GN says: any would-be Type II blow-up
profile, when viewed in normalized coordinates, has infinite
dissipation. Thus such profiles cannot arise from finite-cost
trajectories. Under Axiom SC, this is not an additional assumption but a
theorem (see Theorem 6.2).

\hypertarget{preparatory-lemmas}{%
\section{Preparatory Lemmas}\label{preparatory-lemmas}}

The following lemmas provide the technical foundation for the resolution
theorems. They translate the abstract axioms into concrete analytical
tools.

\begin{lemma}[Compactness extraction]
Assume Axiom C. Let $(x_n) \subset K_E$ be a sequence in an energy sublevel. Then there exist:
\end{lemma}

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  a subsequence \((x_{n_k})\),
\item
  elements \(g_k \in G\),
\item
  a limit point \(x_\infty \in X\) with \(\Phi(x_\infty) \leq E\),
\end{itemize}

such that \(g_k \cdot x_{n_k} \to x_\infty\) in \(X\).

\begin{proof}
Axiom C directly asserts precompactness modulo $G$. Apply the definition to the sequence $(x_n)$ to obtain $g_n \in G$ and a subsequence such that $g_{n_k} \cdot x_{n_k}$ converges. The limit $x_\infty$ satisfies $\Phi(x_\infty) \leq E$ by lower semicontinuity of $\Phi$.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}[Dissipation chain rule]
Assume Axiom D. For any trajectory $u(t) = S_t x$, the function $t \mapsto \Phi(u(t))$ satisfies, for almost every $t \in [0, T_*(x))$:
$$
\frac{d}{dt} \Phi(u(t)) \leq -\alpha \mathfrak{D}(u(t)) + C.
$$
In particular, $\Phi(u(t))$ is absolutely continuous and
$$
\Phi(u(t)) \leq \Phi(u(0)) + Ct - \alpha \int_0^t \mathfrak{D}(u(s)) \, ds.
$$
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
Fix $t_1 < t_2$ in $[0, T_*(x))$. By Axiom D:
$$
\Phi(u(t_2)) + \alpha \int_{t_1}^{t_2} \mathfrak{D}(u(s)) \, ds \leq \Phi(u(t_1)) + C(t_2 - t_1).
$$
Rearranging:
$$
\Phi(u(t_2)) - \Phi(u(t_1)) \leq C(t_2 - t_1) - \alpha \int_{t_1}^{t_2} \mathfrak{D}(u(s)) \, ds.
$$
This shows $\Phi(u(\cdot))$ has bounded variation on compact intervals. Since $\mathfrak{D}(u(\cdot)) \in L^1_{\mathrm{loc}}$, the function $t \mapsto \int_0^t \mathfrak{D}(u(s)) \, ds$ is absolutely continuous. Thus $\Phi(u(\cdot))$ is absolutely continuous, and the differential inequality holds a.e.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}[Cost-recovery duality]
Assume Axioms D and Rec. For any trajectory $u(t) = S_t x$:
$$
\mathrm{Leb}\{t \in [0, T) : u(t) \notin \mathcal{G}\} \leq \frac{C_0}{r_0} \mathcal{C}_T(x).
$$
In particular, if $\mathcal{C}_*(x) < \infty$, then $u(t) \in \mathcal{G}$ for almost all sufficiently large $t$.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
Let $A = \{t \in [0, T) : u(t) \notin \mathcal{G}\}$. By Axiom Rec:
$$
r_0 \cdot \mathrm{Leb}(A) \leq \int_A \mathcal{R}(u(t)) \, dt \leq C_0 \int_0^T \mathfrak{D}(u(t)) \, dt = C_0 \mathcal{C}_T(x).
$$
Dividing by $r_0$ gives the result. If $\mathcal{C}_*(x) < \infty$, then $\mathrm{Leb}(A) < \infty$ for $T = T_*(x)$, so $A$ has finite measure.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}[Occupation measure bounds]
Assume Axiom Cap. For any measurable set $B \subseteq X$ with $\mathrm{Cap}(B) > 0$ and any trajectory $u(t) = S_t x$:
$$
\mathrm{Leb}\{t \in [0, T] : u(t) \in B\} \leq \frac{C_{\mathrm{cap}}(\Phi(x) + T)}{\mathrm{Cap}(B)}.
$$
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
Define the occupation time $\tau_B := \mathrm{Leb}\{t \in [0, T] : u(t) \in B\}$. We have:
$$
\mathrm{Cap}(B) \cdot \tau_B = \int_0^T \mathrm{Cap}(B) \mathbf{1}_{u(t) \in B} \, dt \leq \int_0^T c(u(t)) \mathbf{1}_{u(t) \in B} \, dt \leq \int_0^T c(u(t)) \, dt.
$$
By Axiom Cap, the last integral is bounded by $C_{\mathrm{cap}}(\Phi(x) + T)$.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}[High-capacity sets are avoided]
If $(B_k)$ is a sequence with $\mathrm{Cap}(B_k) \to \infty$, then for any fixed trajectory:
$$
\lim_{k \to \infty} \mathrm{Leb}\{t \in [0, T] : u(t) \in B_k\} = 0.
$$
\end{corollary}

\begin{lemma}[Łojasiewicz decay estimate]
Assume Axioms D and LS with $C = 0$ (strict Lyapunov). Suppose $u(t) = S_t x$ remains in the neighbourhood $U$ of the safe manifold $M$ for all $t \geq t_0$. Then:
$$
\mathrm{dist}(u(t), M) \leq C \cdot (t - t_0 + 1)^{-\theta/(1-\theta)} \quad \text{for all } t \geq t_0,
$$
where $C$ depends on $\Phi(u(t_0))$, $\alpha$, $C_{\mathrm{LS}}$, and $\theta$.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
Let $\psi(t) := \Phi(u(t)) - \Phi_{\min} \geq 0$. By Lemma 5.20 (with $C = 0$):
$$
\psi'(t) \leq -\alpha \mathfrak{D}(u(t)) \quad \text{a.e.}
$$
We need to relate $\mathfrak{D}$ to $\psi$. From gradient flow structure (or analogous dissipation-height coupling in the general case), assume:
$$
\mathfrak{D}(x) \geq c |\nabla \Phi(x)|^2 \quad \text{and} \quad |\nabla \Phi(x)| \geq c' (\Phi(x) - \Phi_{\min})^{1-\theta}
$$
near $M$ (the Łojasiewicz gradient inequality). Then:
$$
\psi'(t) \leq -\alpha c (c')^2 \psi(t)^{2(1-\theta)} = -\beta \psi(t)^{2-2\theta}
$$
for some $\beta > 0$.

For $\theta < 1$, set $\gamma = 2 - 2\theta > 0$. Then:
$$
\frac{d}{dt} \psi^{1-\gamma} = (1 - \gamma) \psi^{-\gamma} \psi' \leq -\beta(1 - \gamma) < 0.
$$
Since $1 - \gamma = 2\theta - 1$, we have for $\theta > 1/2$:
$$
\psi(t)^{2\theta - 1} \leq \psi(t_0)^{2\theta - 1} - \beta(2\theta - 1)(t - t_0),
$$
giving polynomial decay of $\psi(t)$ and hence of $\mathrm{dist}(u(t), M)$ via the Łojasiewicz inequality. The general case $\theta \in (0, 1]$ follows by similar ODE analysis.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}[Herbst argument]
Assume an invariant probability measure $\mu$ satisfies a log-Sobolev inequality with constant $\lambda_{\mathrm{LS}} > 0$. Then for any Lipschitz function $F: X \to \mathbb{R}$ with Lipschitz constant $\|F\|_{\mathrm{Lip}} \leq 1$:
$$
\mu\left(\left\{x : F(x) - \int F \, d\mu > r\right\}\right) \leq \exp\left(-\lambda_{\mathrm{LS}} r^2 / 2\right).
$$
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
For $\lambda > 0$, set $f = e^{\lambda F / 2}$. By the log-Sobolev inequality (LSI):
$$
\int f^2 \log f^2 \, d\mu - \int f^2 \, d\mu \log \int f^2 \, d\mu \leq \frac{1}{2\lambda_{\mathrm{LS}}} \int |\nabla f|^2 \, d\mu.
$$
Since $|\nabla f| = \frac{\lambda}{2} |f| |\nabla F| \leq \frac{\lambda}{2} f$ (using $\|F\|_{\mathrm{Lip}} \leq 1$):
$$
\int |\nabla f|^2 \, d\mu \leq \frac{\lambda^2}{4} \int f^2 \, d\mu.
$$
Let $Z(\lambda) = \int e^{\lambda F} \, d\mu$. The entropy inequality becomes:
$$
\frac{d}{d\lambda}\left[\lambda \log Z(\lambda)\right] = \log Z(\lambda) + \frac{\lambda Z'(\lambda)}{Z(\lambda)} \leq \frac{\lambda}{8\lambda_{\mathrm{LS}}}.
$$
Integrating and using Chebyshev's inequality yields the Gaussian concentration.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}[Sector suppression from LSI]
If the action functional $\mathcal{A}$ satisfies $\|\mathcal{A}\|_{\mathrm{Lip}} \leq L$ and Axiom TB1 holds with gap $\Delta$, then:
$$
\mu(\{x : \tau(x) \neq 0\}) \leq \mu(\{x : \mathcal{A}(x) \geq \mathcal{A}_{\min} + \Delta\}) \leq C \exp\left(-\frac{\lambda_{\mathrm{LS}} \Delta^2}{2L^2}\right).
$$
\end{corollary}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\emph{Goal: Concrete systems and the barrier zoo}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{chapter-3-the-axiom-system}{%
\chapter{Chapter 3: The Axiom System}\label{chapter-3-the-axiom-system}}

A \textbf{hypostructure} is a structural flow datum \(\mathcal{S}\)
satisfying the following axioms. The axioms are organized by their role
in constraining system behavior.

\hypertarget{axiom-layers-structure-learning-and-universality}{%
\section{Axiom Layers: Structure, Learning, and
Universality}\label{axiom-layers-structure-learning-and-universality}}

The hypostructure axioms organize into \textbf{three layers of
increasing abstraction}. Each layer subsumes the previous, enabling
progressively more powerful machinery:

\textbf{Layer S (Structural Axioms).} The core axioms C.0, D.0, SC.0,
LS.0, Cap.0, TB.0, GC.0, and R define what a valid hypostructure must
satisfy. These are the mathematical constraints---energy balance,
dissipation, scale coherence, capacity bounds, and dictionary
correspondence.

\emph{What S-Layer enables:} Metatheorems 19.4.A--N (local-to-global
globalization, obstruction collapse, stiff pairings, categorical
obstruction, master structural resolution). With only the S-layer, the
framework provides structural resolution: every trajectory either
converges to an attractor, exits to infinity in a controlled way, or
fails in a classified mode.

\textbf{Layer L (Learning Axioms).} Three additional hypotheses enable
the computational machinery:

\begin{itemize}
\item
  \textbf{L1 (Representational Completeness):} A parametric family
  \(\Theta\) is dense in admissible structures---every hypostructure can
  be approximated to arbitrary precision. \emph{Justified by Theorem
  13.40 (Axiom-Expressivity).}
\item
  \textbf{L2 (Persistent Excitation):} Training data distinguishes
  structures---no two genuinely different hypostructures produce
  identical defect signatures. \emph{Ensures identifiability from finite
  data.}
\item
  \textbf{L3 (Non-Degenerate Parametrization):} The map
  \(\theta \mapsto \mathbb{H}(\theta)\) is locally Lipschitz and
  injective---small parameter changes yield small structural changes,
  and distinct parameters yield distinct structures. \emph{Justified by
  Theorem 14.30 (Meta-Identifiability).}
\end{itemize}

\emph{What L-Layer enables:} The analytic properties assumed in the
S-layer become \textbf{derivable theorems}:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|}
\hline
\textbf{Property} & \textbf{Derived Via} & \textbf{Theorem} \\
\hline
Global Coercivity & L3 (Identifiability) & 14.30 \\
Global Height & L1 + meta-learning & 19.4.D \\
Subcritical Scaling & L1 + meta-learning & 19.4.E \\
Stiffness & L1 + meta-learning & 19.4.F \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

\textbf{Layer \(\Omega\) (AGI Limit).} The theoretical limit---reduces
all L-layer assumptions to a single meta-hypothesis. The key insight is
that several L-axioms become derivable under stronger conditions:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \emph{S1 (Admissibility) becomes diagnostic:} The framework tests
  regularity rather than assuming it (Theorem 15.21).
\item
  \emph{L2 (Excitation) eliminated:} Active Probing (Theorem 13.44)
  generates persistently exciting data.
\item
  \emph{L3 (Identifiability) relaxed:} Singular Learning Theory
  (Watanabe) shows that the RLCT controls convergence even in degenerate
  landscapes.
\item
  \emph{L1 (Expressivity) weakened:} Replace fixed \(\Theta\) with a
  hierarchy \(\Theta_1 \subset \Theta_2 \subset \cdots\) of increasing
  expressivity.
\end{enumerate}

This yields \textbf{Axiom \(\Omega\) (AGI Limit):} Access to a learning
agent \(\mathcal{A}\) equipped with: - \emph{Universal Approximation:}
\(\Theta = \bigcup_n \Theta_n\) dense in continuous functionals on
trajectory data. - \emph{Optimal Experiment Design:} Ability to probe
system \(S\) and observe trajectories. - \emph{Defect Minimization:}
Optimization oracle for the axiom risk \(\mathcal{R}(\theta)\).

\textbf{Hypothesis \(\Omega\) (Universal Structural Approximation):}
System \(S\) belongs to the closure of computable
hypostructures---physics approximable by finite combination of (Energy,
Dissipation, Symmetry, Topology).

\emph{What \(\Omega\)-Layer enables:} \textbf{Metatheorem 0 (Convergence
of Structure)}, combining Theorems 13.44, 13.40, and 15.25: 1. If \(S\)
is regular \(\Rightarrow\) \(\mathcal{A}\) converges to \(\theta^*\)
satisfying all structural axioms. 2. If \(S\) is singular
\(\Rightarrow\) non-zero defects classify the failure mode (Response
Signature). 3. Analytic properties (global bounds, coercivity,
stiffness) emerge as properties of \(\theta^*\).

\textbf{User perspective.} The three layers are not competing
alternatives---they form a hierarchy. A user works at the layer
appropriate to their verification capability:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \emph{S-layer only:} Verify structural axioms directly \(\Rightarrow\)
  apply metatheorems 19.4.A--N.
\item
  \emph{S + L layers:} Verify learning axioms \(\Rightarrow\) derive
  S-properties as theorems, not assumptions.
\item
  \emph{\(\Omega\)-layer:} Assume universal structural approximation
  \(\Rightarrow\) derive L-properties from universal approximation.
\end{itemize}

The development in Parts III--VI focuses on the S-layer. Part VII
develops the L-layer. The full \(\Omega\)-layer machinery appears in
Section 18.3.5.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{conservation-constraints}{%
\section{Conservation constraints}\label{conservation-constraints}}

These axioms govern energy balance and recovery mechanisms---the
thermodynamic backbone of the framework. The mathematical treatment
draws on Prigogine's theory of dissipative structures
\autocite{Prigogine78} and the Jarzynski equality \autocite{Jarzynski97}
connecting nonequilibrium processes to equilibrium free energies.

\hypertarget{axiom-d-dissipation}{%
\subsection{Axiom D (Dissipation)}\label{axiom-d-dissipation}}

\begin{axiom}[D (Dissipation bound along trajectories)]
Along any trajectory $u(t) = S_t x$, there exists $\alpha > 0$ such that for all $0 \leq t_1 \leq t_2 < T_*(x)$:
$$
\Phi(u(t_2)) + \alpha \int_{t_1}^{t_2} \mathfrak{D}(u(s)) \, ds \leq \Phi(u(t_1)) + C_{u}(t_1, t_2),
$$
where the \textbf{drift term} $C_u(t_1, t_2)$ satisfies:
\end{axiom}

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{On the good region \(\mathcal{G}\):} \(C_u(t_1, t_2) = 0\)
  when \(u(s) \in \mathcal{G}\) for all \(s \in [t_1, t_2]\).
\item
  \textbf{Outside \(\mathcal{G}\):}
  \(C_u(t_1, t_2) \leq C \cdot \mathrm{Leb}\{s \in [t_1, t_2] : u(s) \notin \mathcal{G}\}\)
  for some constant \(C \geq 0\).
\end{itemize}

\textbf{Fallback (Mode C.E: Energy Blow-up).} When Axiom D fails---i.e.,
the energy grows without bound---the trajectory exhibits \textbf{energy
blow-up}. The drift term is uncontrolled, leading to
\(\Phi(u(t)) \to \infty\) as \(t \nearrow T_*(x)\).

\textbf{Role in constraint class.} Axiom D provides the fundamental
energy--dissipation balance. It ensures that energy cannot increase
without bound unless the system remains outside the good region
\(\mathcal{G}\) for an extended time. The drift term controls energy
growth outside \(\mathcal{G}\), and is regulated by Axiom Rec.

\begin{corollary}[Integral bound]
For any trajectory with finite time in bad regions (guaranteed by Axiom Rec when $\mathcal{C}_*(x) < \infty$):
$$
\int_0^{T_*(x)} \mathfrak{D}(u(t)) \, dt \leq \frac{1}{\alpha}\left(\Phi(x) - \Phi_{\min} + C \cdot \tau_{\mathrm{bad}}\right),
$$
where $\tau_{\mathrm{bad}} = \mathrm{Leb}\{t : u(t) \notin \mathcal{G}\}$ is finite by Axiom Rec.
\end{corollary}

\textbf{Remark 3.2 (Connection to entropy methods).} In gradient flow
and entropy method contexts: - \(\Phi\) is the free energy or relative
entropy, - \(\mathfrak{D}\) is the entropy production rate or Fisher
information, - The inequality becomes the entropy--entropy production
inequality, - The drift \(C_u = 0\) on the good region is the
entropy-dissipation identity.

\hypertarget{axiom-rec-recovery}{%
\subsection{Axiom Rec (Recovery)}\label{axiom-rec-recovery}}

\begin{axiom}[Rec (Recovery inequality along trajectories)]
Along any trajectory $u(t) = S_t x$, there exist:
\end{axiom}

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  a measurable subset \(\mathcal{G} \subseteq X\) called the
  \textbf{good region},
\item
  a measurable function \(\mathcal{R}: X \to [0, \infty)\) called the
  \textbf{recovery functional},
\item
  a constant \(C_0 > 0\),
\end{itemize}

such that:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Positivity outside \(\mathcal{G}\):} \(\mathcal{R}(x) > 0\)
  for all \(x \in X \mathbin{\backslash}\mathcal{G}\) (spatially
  varying, not necessarily uniform),
\item
  \textbf{Recovery inequality:} For any interval
  \([t_1, t_2] \subset [0, T_*(x))\) during which
  \(u(t) \in X \mathbin{\backslash}\mathcal{G}\): \[
  \int_{t_1}^{t_2} \mathcal{R}(u(s)) \, ds \leq C_0 \int_{t_1}^{t_2} \mathfrak{D}(u(s)) \, ds.
  \]
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Fallback (Mode C.E: Energy Blow-up).} When Axiom Rec
fails---i.e., recovery is impossible along a trajectory---the trajectory
enters a \textbf{failure region} \(\mathcal{F}\) where the drift term in
Axiom D is uncontrolled, leading to energy blow-up.

\textbf{Role in constraint class.} Axiom Rec is the dual to Axiom D: it
bounds the time a trajectory can spend outside the good region
\(\mathcal{G}\) in terms of dissipation cost. Together, D and Rec ensure
that finite-cost trajectories cannot drift indefinitely in bad regions.
The recovery functional \(\mathcal{R}\) may vary spatially---some bad
regions have fast recovery (large \(\mathcal{R}\)), others slow recovery
(small \(\mathcal{R}\)).

\begin{proposition}[Time bound outside good region]
Under Axioms D and Rec, for any trajectory with finite total cost $\mathcal{C}_*(x) < \infty$, define $r_{\min}(u) := \inf_{t : u(t) \notin \mathcal{G}} \mathcal{R}(u(t))$. If $r_{\min}(u) > 0$:
$$
\mathrm{Leb}\{t \in [0, T_*(x)) : u(t) \notin \mathcal{G}\} \leq \frac{C_0}{r_{\min}(u)} \mathcal{C}_*(x).
$$
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Let $A = \{t : u(t) \notin \mathcal{G}\}$. Then
$$
r_{\min}(u) \cdot \mathrm{Leb}(A) \leq \int_A \mathcal{R}(u(t)) \, dt \leq C_0 \int_0^{T_*(x)} \mathfrak{D}(u(t)) \, dt = C_0 \mathcal{C}_*(x).
$$
\end{proof}

\textbf{Remark 3.4 (Adaptive recovery).} The recovery rate
\(\mathcal{R}(x)\) may vary spatially. Only the trajectory-specific
minimum \(r_{\min}(u)\) matters, and this is positive whenever Axiom Rec
holds along that trajectory.

\hypertarget{the-recovery-correspondence-duality}{%
\subsection{The Recovery-Correspondence
Duality}\label{the-recovery-correspondence-duality}}

Axiom Rec (Recovery) and Axiom Rep (Structural Correspondence,
Definition 16.1) govern distinct aspects of the same phenomenon: the
capacity of a state to maintain structural coherence. This subsection
establishes their categorical equivalence.

\begin{proposition}[Recovery-Dictionary Isomorphism]
*Let $\mathbb{H}$ be a hypostructure equipped with Recovery functional $\mathcal{R}$ (Axiom Rec), and suppose the Dictionary map $D: X \to \mathcal{T}$ (Axiom Rep) exists. Then the Recovery functional admits the representation:*
\end{proposition}

\[\mathcal{R}(u) = \|D(u) - D^{-1}(D(u))\|_{\mathcal{T}}\]

\emph{where the norm quantifies the invertibility defect of the
Dictionary.}

\emph{Structural interpretation:} - If Axiom Rep holds (the Dictionary
is an equivalence), then \(D^{-1} \circ D = \mathrm{id}\), whence
\(\mathcal{R}(u) = 0\) for all \(u \in X\), placing every state in the
good region \(\mathcal{G}\). - If Axiom Rep fails (the Dictionary is not
invertible), then \(\mathcal{R}(u) > 0\) measures the distance from the
structurally coherent regime.

\begin{proof}
We establish the equivalence via the constraint class structure.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item[\textbf{Step 1}] \textbf{(Recovery Implies Dictionary Coherence).}
    Assume Axiom Rec holds with recovery inequality $\int \mathcal{R}(u(s)) \, ds \leq C_0 \int \mathfrak{D}(u(s)) \, ds$. Define the effective Dictionary defect:
    $$\delta_D(u) := \inf\{\|u - v\| : v \in \ker(\alpha_D \circ \iota_D - \mathrm{id})\}$$
    where $\iota_D$ denotes instantiation and $\alpha_D$ denotes abstraction (Definition 16.1). The recovery functional controls this defect: $\delta_D(u) \leq C \cdot \mathcal{R}(u)$ for some constant $C > 0$.

    \item[\textbf{Step 2}] \textbf{(Dictionary Coherence Implies Recovery).}
    Conversely, suppose the Dictionary is $\varepsilon$-invertible, i.e., $\|D^{-1}(D(u)) - u\| \leq \varepsilon$ for all $u \in X$. Setting $\mathcal{R}(u) := \|D(u) - D^{-1}(D(u))\|$ yields the recovery inequality with constant $C_0$ depending on the Lipschitz constant of $D$.

    \item[\textbf{Step 3}] \textbf{(Good Region Characterization).}
    The good region admits the characterization:
    $$\mathcal{G} = \{u \in X : D^{-1}(D(u)) = u\} = \ker(\mathcal{R})$$
    consisting precisely of states for which the Dictionary is exact.
\end{enumerate}
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}[Unified Failure Mechanism]
*A trajectory fails to recover (violates Axiom Repec) if and only if its structural dictionary degrades (violates Axiom Repep). This establishes the equivalence of Conservation and Duality failures.*
\end{corollary}

\textbf{Remark 3.17.2 (Dual Perspectives).} Axiom Rec and Axiom Rep
encode complementary perspectives on the same structural constraint:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|}
\hline
\textbf{Perspective} & \textbf{Axiom} & \textbf{Quantity Measured} & \textbf{Domain} \\
\hline
\textbf{Dynamical} & Rec & Dissipation cost to return to $\mathcal{G}$ & Trajectory space \\
\textbf{Representational} & R & Fidelity of structural translation & Dictionary space \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

The dynamical formulation quantifies persistence outside the good
region; the representational formulation quantifies translation accuracy
between domains. The isomorphism demonstrates these to be equivalent
characterizations.

\textbf{Example 3.17.3 (Fluid dynamics).} For the Navier-Stokes
equations, let \(D\) denote the Fourier-Littlewood-Paley decomposition
mapping velocity fields to frequency-localized components. The recovery
functional \(\mathcal{R}(u) = \|u - P_{\leq N} u\|\) measures
high-frequency content. States satisfying \(\mathcal{R}(u) = 0\) (purely
low-frequency) constitute the good region where finite-dimensional
Galerkin approximations are exact.

\textbf{Example 3.17.4 (Optimal transport).} For gradient flows on
\(\mathcal{P}_2(\mathbb{R}^n)\), let \(D\) map probability measures to
truncated moment sequences. The recovery functional
\(\mathcal{R}(\mu) = W_2(\mu, \hat{\mu}_N)\) measures the Wasserstein
distance to the \(N\)-moment reconstruction \(\hat{\mu}_N\). The good
region comprises measures fully determined by finitely many moments,
including Gaussian measures.

\hypertarget{topology-constraints}{%
\section{Topology constraints}\label{topology-constraints}}

These axioms govern spatial structure and geometric
concentration---where and how mass can accumulate.

\hypertarget{axiom-tb-topological-background}{%
\subsection{Axiom TB (Topological
Background)}\label{axiom-tb-topological-background}}

\textbf{Structural Data (Topological sector structure).} The system
admits a topological sector structure: - a discrete (or locally finite)
index set \(\mathcal{T}\), - a measurable function
\(\tau: X \to \mathcal{T}\) called the \textbf{sector index}, - a
distinguished element \(0 \in \mathcal{T}\) called the \textbf{trivial
sector}, - an \textbf{action functional}
\(\mathcal{A}: X \to [0, \infty]\) measuring topological cost.

The sector index is \textbf{flow-invariant}: \(\tau(S_t x) = \tau(x)\)
for all \(t \in [0, T_*(x))\).

\begin{axiom}[TB1 (Action gap)]
There exists $\Delta > 0$ such that for all $x$ with $\tau(x) \neq 0$:
$$
\mathcal{A}(x) \geq \mathcal{A}_{\min} + \Delta,
$$
where $\mathcal{A}_{\min} = \inf_{x: \tau(x) = 0} \mathcal{A}(x)$.
\end{axiom}

\begin{axiom}[TB2 (Action-height coupling)]
The action is controlled by the height: there exists $C_{\mathcal{A}} > 0$ such that
$$
\mathcal{A}(x) \leq C_{\mathcal{A}} \Phi(x).
$$
\end{axiom}

\textbf{Fallback (Mode T.E: Topological Obstruction).} When Axiom TB
fails along a trajectory---i.e., the trajectory is constrained to a
nontrivial topological sector \(\tau \neq 0\) with action exceeding the
gap---topological invariants prevent the singularity from forming.

\textbf{Role in constraint class.} Axiom TB provides topological
obstructions to concentration. Nontrivial topological sectors (e.g.,
nonzero degree, Chern number, homotopy class) carry a minimum action
cost \(\Delta\). Trajectories in such sectors must pay this action
penalty, which may exceed the available energy budget, thereby blocking
singularity formation.

\textbf{Example 3.5 (Topological charges).}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Degree:} For maps \(u: S^n \to S^n\),
  \(\tau(u) = \deg(u) \in \mathbb{Z}\).
\item
  \textbf{Chern number:} For connections on a bundle,
  \(\tau(A) = c_1(A) \in \mathbb{Z}\).
\item
  \textbf{Homotopy class:} \(\tau(u) = [u] \in \pi_n(M)\).
\item
  \textbf{Vorticity:} \(\tau(u) = \int \omega \, dx\) for fluid flows.
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{axiom-cap-capacity}{%
\subsection{Axiom Cap (Capacity)}\label{axiom-cap-capacity}}

\begin{axiom}[Cap (Capacity bound along trajectories)]
Along any trajectory $u(t) = S_t x$, there exist:
\end{axiom}

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  a measurable function \(c: X \to [0, \infty]\) called the
  \textbf{capacity density},
\item
  constants \(C_{\mathrm{cap}} > 0\) and \(C_0 \geq 0\),
\end{itemize}

such that the capacity integral is controlled by the dissipation budget:
\[
\int_0^{\min(T, T_*(x))} c(u(t)) \, dt \leq C_{\mathrm{cap}} \int_0^{\min(T, T_*(x))} \mathfrak{D}(u(t)) \, dt + C_0 \Phi(x).
\]

\textbf{Fallback (Mode C.D: Geometric Concentration).} When Axiom Cap
fails along a trajectory---i.e., the trajectory concentrates on
high-capacity sets without commensurate dissipation---the trajectory
exhibits \textbf{geometric concentration} that violates the capacity
barrier.

\textbf{Role in constraint class.} Axiom Cap quantifies geometric
accessibility: trajectories can only occupy high-capacity regions if
they are actively dissipating. It prevents passive accumulation in thin
or singular structures. Capacity is tied to dissipation, not
time---spending time in high-capacity regions requires dissipation
budget.

\begin{definition}[Capacity of a set]
The \textbf{capacity} of a measurable set $B \subseteq X$ is
$$
\mathrm{Cap}(B) := \inf_{x \in B} c(x).
$$
\end{definition}

\begin{proposition}[Occupation time bound]
Under Axiom Cap, for any trajectory with finite cost $\mathcal{C}_T(x) < \infty$ and any set $B$ with $\mathrm{Cap}(B) > 0$:
$$
\mathrm{Leb}\{t \in [0, T] : u(t) \in B\} \leq \frac{C_{\mathrm{cap}} \mathcal{C}_T(x) + C_0 \Phi(x)}{\mathrm{Cap}(B)}.
$$
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Let $\tau_B = \mathrm{Leb}\{t \in [0, T] : u(t) \in B\}$. Then
$$
\mathrm{Cap}(B) \cdot \tau_B \leq \int_0^T c(u(t)) \mathbf{1}_{u(t) \in B} \, dt \leq \int_0^T c(u(t)) \, dt \leq C_{\mathrm{cap}} \mathcal{C}_T(x) + C_0 \Phi(x).
$$
\end{proof}

\textbf{Remark 3.8.} Capacity measures how ``expensive'' (in dissipation
cost) it is to visit a region. High-capacity sets are accessible only to
trajectories with high dissipation budgets.

\hypertarget{duality-constraints}{%
\section{Duality constraints}\label{duality-constraints}}

These axioms enforce compactness and scaling balance---the self-similar
structure of concentrating solutions.

\hypertarget{axiom-c-compactness}{%
\subsection{Axiom C (Compactness)}\label{axiom-c-compactness}}

\textbf{Structural Data (Symmetry Group).} The system admits a
continuous action by a locally compact topological group \(G\) acting on
\(X\) by isometries (i.e., \(d(g \cdot x, g \cdot y) = d(x, y)\) for all
\(g \in G\), \(x, y \in X\)). This is structural data about the system,
not an assumption to be verified per trajectory.

\begin{axiom}[C (Structural Compactness Potential)]
We say a trajectory $u(t) = S_t x$ with bounded energy $\sup_{t < T_*(x)} \Phi(u(t)) \leq E < \infty$ \textbf{satisfies Axiom C} if: for every sequence of times $t_n \nearrow T_*(x)$, there exists a subsequence $(t_{n_k})$ and elements $g_k \in G$ such that $(g_k \cdot u(t_{n_k}))$ converges \textbf{strongly} in the topology of $X$ to a \textbf{single} limit profile $V \in X$.
\end{axiom}

When \(G\) is trivial, this reduces to ordinary precompactness of
bounded-energy trajectory tails.

\textbf{Fallback (Mode D.D: Dispersion/Global Existence).} If Axiom C
fails (energy disperses), there is \textbf{no finite-time
singularity}---the solution exists globally via scattering (dispersion).
This is not a failure mode but \textbf{global existence}: energy
disperses, no concentration occurs, and no singularity forms.

\textbf{Role in constraint class.} Axiom C embodies the forced structure
principle: finite-time blow-up \emph{requires} energy concentration, and
concentration \emph{forces} the emergence of canonical profiles. The
mechanism is:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Finite-time blow-up requires concentration.} To form a
  singularity at \(T_* < \infty\), energy must concentrate---otherwise
  the solution disperses globally and no singularity forms.
\item
  \textbf{Concentration forces local structure.} Wherever energy
  concentrates, a canonical profile \(V\) emerges. Axiom C holds locally
  at any blow-up locus.
\item
  \textbf{No concentration = no singularity.} If Axiom C fails (energy
  disperses), there is no finite-time singularity---the solution exists
  globally via scattering (Mode D.D).
\end{enumerate}

Consequently: - \textbf{Mode D.D is not a singularity.} It represents
global existence via dispersion, not a ``failure mode.'' - \textbf{Modes
S.E--S.D require Axiom C to hold} (structure exists), then test whether
the structure satisfies algebraic permits. - \textbf{No global
compactness proof is needed.} We observe that blow-up forces local
compactness, then check permits on the forced structure.

\textbf{Remark 3.9 (Strong convergence is forced, not assumed).} The
requirement of strong convergence is not an assumption to verify---it is
a \emph{consequence} of energy concentration. If a sequence converges
only weakly (\(u(t_n) \rightharpoonup V\)) with energy loss
(\(\Phi(u(t_n)) \not\to \Phi(V)\)), then energy has dispersed to dust,
no true concentration occurred, and no finite-time singularity forms.
This is Mode D.D: global existence via scattering.

\begin{definition}[Modulus of compactness]
The \textbf{modulus of compactness} along a trajectory $u(t)$ with $\sup_t \Phi(u(t)) \leq E$ is:
$$
\omega_C(\varepsilon, u) := \min\left\{N \in \mathbb{N} : \{u(t) : t < T_*(x)\} \subseteq \bigcup_{i=1}^N g_i \cdot B(x_i, \varepsilon) \text{ for some } g_i \in G, x_i \in X\right\}.
$$
Axiom C holds along a trajectory iff $\omega_C(\varepsilon, u) < \infty$ for all $\varepsilon > 0$.
\end{definition}

\textbf{Remark 3.11.} In the PDE context, concentration behavior is
typically described by: - Rellich--Kondrachov compactness for Sobolev
embeddings, - Aubin--Lions lemma for parabolic regularity, -
Concentration-compactness à la Lions for critical problems
\autocite{Lions84,Lions85}, - Profile decomposition à la
Struwe-Gérard--Bahouri--Chemin for dispersive equations
\autocite{Struwe84}.

\hypertarget{axiom-sc-scaling}{%
\subsection{Axiom SC (Scaling)}\label{axiom-sc-scaling}}

The Scaling Structure axiom provides the minimal geometric data needed
to derive normalization constraints from scaling arithmetic alone. It
applies \textbf{on orbits where the scaling subgroup acts}.

\begin{definition}[Scaling subgroup]
A \textbf{scaling subgroup} is a one-parameter subgroup $(\mathcal{S}_\lambda)_{\lambda > 0} \subset G$ of the symmetry group, with $\mathcal{S}_1 = e$ and $\mathcal{S}_\lambda \circ \mathcal{S}_\mu = \mathcal{S}_{\lambda\mu}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Scaling exponents]
The \textbf{scaling exponents} along an orbit where $(\mathcal{S}_\lambda)$ acts are constants $\alpha > 0$ and $\beta > 0$ such that:
$$
\Phi(\mathcal{S}_\lambda \cdot x) = \lambda^\alpha \Phi(x), \quad t \mapsto S_{\lambda^\beta t}(\mathcal{S}_\lambda \cdot x) = \mathcal{S}_\lambda \cdot S_t(x).
$$
\end{definition}

\begin{axiom}[SC (Scaling Structure on orbits)]
On any orbit where the scaling subgroup $(\mathcal{S}_\lambda)_{\lambda > 0}$ acts with well-defined scaling exponents $(\alpha, \beta)$, the \textbf{subcritical dissipation condition} holds:
$$
\alpha > \beta.
$$
\end{axiom}

\textbf{Fallback (Mode S.E: Supercritical Symmetry Cascade).} When Axiom
SC fails along a trajectory---either because no scaling subgroup acts,
or the subcritical condition \(\alpha > \beta\) is violated---the
trajectory may exhibit \textbf{supercritical symmetry cascade}. Type II
(self-similar) blow-up becomes possible; normalization constraints
cannot exclude it.

\textbf{Role in constraint class.} Axiom SC encodes the dimensional
balance of the system. The exponent \(\alpha\) governs how energy scales
under dilation; \(\beta\) governs how time scales. The condition
\(\alpha > \beta\) ensures that dissipation scales faster than time on
self-similar orbits, rendering Type II blow-up impossible for
finite-cost trajectories. This is a consequence of pure scaling
arithmetic---no additional regularity assumptions are needed.

\textbf{Remark 3.14 (Scaling structure is soft).} For most systems of
interest, the scaling structure is immediate from dimensional analysis:
- For the heat equation: \(\alpha = 2\), \(\beta = 2\) (critical). - For
the nonlinear Schrödinger equation: \(\alpha = d/2 - 1/p\),
\(\beta = 2/p\) (supercritical when \(\alpha < \beta\)). - For the
Navier--Stokes equation in 3D: \(\alpha = 1\), \(\beta = 2\)
(supercritical).

\textbf{Remark 3.15 (Connection to Property GN).} Under Axiom SC,
Property GN (Generic Normalization) becomes a derived consequence rather
than an independent axiom. Any would-be Type II blow-up profile, when
viewed in normalized coordinates, has infinite dissipation. Thus such
profiles cannot arise from finite-cost trajectories.

\hypertarget{symmetry-constraints}{%
\section{Symmetry constraints}\label{symmetry-constraints}}

These axioms enforce local rigidity near equilibria---the stiffness that
drives convergence. The connection between critical point structure and
global topology is formalized by \textbf{Morse theory}
\autocite{Morse34,Witten82}: the number and types of critical points of
a height functional constrain the topology of the underlying manifold.
Witten's supersymmetric approach \autocite{Witten82} provides the
physical derivation of cohomology from energy landscapes.

\hypertarget{axiom-ls-local-stiffness}{%
\subsection{Axiom LS (Local Stiffness)}\label{axiom-ls-local-stiffness}}

\begin{axiom}[LS (Local stiffness / Łojasiewicz–Simon inequality [@Simon83])]
In a neighbourhood of the safe manifold, there exist:
\end{axiom}

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  a closed subset \(M \subseteq X\) called the \textbf{safe manifold}
  (the set of equilibria, ground states, or canonical patterns),
\item
  an open neighbourhood \(U \supseteq M\),
\item
  constants \(\theta \in (0, 1]\) and \(C_{\mathrm{LS}} > 0\),
\end{itemize}

such that:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Minimum on \(M\):} \(\Phi\) attains its infimum on \(M\):
  \(\Phi_{\min} := \inf_{x \in X} \Phi(x) = \inf_{x \in M} \Phi(x)\),
\item
  \textbf{Łojasiewicz--Simon inequality:} For all \(x \in U\): \[
  \Phi(x) - \Phi_{\min} \geq C_{\mathrm{LS}} \cdot \mathrm{dist}(x, M)^{1/\theta}.
  \]
\item
  \textbf{Drift domination inside \(U\):} Along any trajectory
  \(u(t) = S_t x\) that remains in \(U\) on some interval
  \([t_0, t_1]\), the drift is strictly dominated by dissipation: \[
  \frac{d}{dt}\Phi(u(t)) \leq -c \mathfrak{D}(u(t)) \quad \text{for some } c > 0 \text{ and a.e. } t \in [t_0, t_1].
  \]
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Fallback (Mode S.D: Stiffness Breakdown).} Axiom LS is
\textbf{local by design}: it applies only in the neighbourhood \(U\) of
\(M\). A trajectory exhibits \textbf{stiffness breakdown} if any of the
following occur: - The trajectory approaches the boundary of \(U\)
without converging to \(M\), - The Łojasiewicz inequality (condition 2)
fails, - The drift domination (condition 3) fails---i.e., drift pushes
the trajectory away from \(M\) despite being inside \(U\).

Outside \(U\), other axioms (C, D, Rec) govern behaviour.

\textbf{Role in constraint class.} Axiom LS provides local rigidity near
equilibria. The Łojasiewicz--Simon inequality quantifies the
``steepness'' of the energy landscape near \(M\): the exponent
\(\theta\) controls how degenerate the energy is at equilibria. When
\(\theta = 1\), this is a linear coercivity condition; smaller values
indicate stronger degeneracy. The drift domination ensures that
trajectories inside \(U\) are inexorably pulled toward \(M\) by
dissipation. This formalizes the concept of \textbf{Inertial Manifolds}
in infinite-dimensional dynamical systems \autocite{Temam88}, which
contain the global attractor and capture the long-time dynamics of
dissipative PDEs.

\textbf{Remark 3.16.} The exponent \(\theta\) is called the
\textbf{Łojasiewicz exponent}. It determines the rate of convergence to
equilibrium.

\textbf{Remark 3.16b (The Spectral-Łojasiewicz Correspondence).} While
Axiom LS is formulated generally via the Łojasiewicz inequality
\(\|\nabla \Phi(u)\| \geq C|\Phi(u) - \Phi_\infty|^\theta\), this
geometric condition encodes the spectral properties of the linearized
operator \(L = \nabla^2 \Phi(u_\infty)\). The exponent \(\theta\)
classifies the physical nature of the stability:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{The Mass Gap Case (\(\theta = 1/2\)):} If \(\theta = 1/2\),
  the inequality is equivalent to \textbf{Strict Convexity} of the
  height functional near the equilibrium.

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \emph{Dynamics:} Exponential decay to equilibrium
    (\(e^{-\lambda t}\)).
  \item
    \emph{Physics:} This corresponds to a \textbf{Mass Gap} (strictly
    positive spectrum, \(\lambda_1 > 0\)). The potential well is
    quadratic.
  \item
    \emph{Example:} Gauge theories with confinement, damped harmonic
    oscillator.
  \end{itemize}
\item
  \textbf{The Degenerate Case (\(\theta \in (0, 1/2)\)):} If
  \(\theta < 1/2\), the potential well is ``flat'' at the bottom (e.g.,
  quartic potential \(x^4\) where \(\theta = 1/4\)).

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \emph{Dynamics:} Polynomial decay (\(t^{-p}\)).
  \item
    \emph{Physics:} This corresponds to \textbf{gapless modes} or
    critical slowing down (zero eigenvalue, \(\lambda_1 = 0\)), but
    where non-linear terms still enforce stability.
  \item
    \emph{Example:} Critical phase transitions, certain
    reaction-diffusion systems.
  \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Proposition 3.16c (Spectral-Łojasiewicz Equivalence).}
\(\theta = 1/2 \iff \lambda_1 > 0\) (mass gap).

\begin{proof}
We establish both directions.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item[\textbf{Step 1}] \textbf{($\Rightarrow$).}
    Suppose $\theta = 1/2$. Near equilibrium $u_\infty$, expand
    $$
    \Phi(u) = \Phi(u_\infty) + \frac{1}{2}\langle L(u - u_\infty), u - u_\infty \rangle + O(\|u - u_\infty\|^3).
    $$
    The Łojasiewicz inequality $\|\nabla \Phi\| \geq C|\Phi - \Phi_\infty|^{1/2}$ implies $\|L(u - u_\infty)\| \geq C'\|u - u_\infty\|$, hence $L \succ \lambda_1 I$ with $\lambda_1 > 0$.

    \item[\textbf{Step 2}] \textbf{($\Leftarrow$).}
    Suppose $L \succ \lambda_1 I$. Then $\Phi(u) - \Phi_\infty \geq \frac{\lambda_1}{2}\|u - u_\infty\|^2$ and $\|\nabla \Phi(u)\| = \|L(u - u_\infty)\| \geq \lambda_1\|u - u_\infty\|$. Combining:
    $$
    \|\nabla \Phi\| \geq \lambda_1 \cdot \sqrt{\frac{2}{\lambda_1}} \cdot |\Phi - \Phi_\infty|^{1/2} = \sqrt{2\lambda_1} \cdot |\Phi - \Phi_\infty|^{1/2}.
    $$
    This is the Łojasiewicz inequality with $\theta = 1/2$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{proof}

\textbf{Corollary 3.16d (Mass Gap Detection).} Axiom LS provides the
\textbf{geometric measuring stick} for the mass gap: proving a mass gap
(as in gauge theories) is equivalent to proving Axiom LS holds with the
specific exponent \(\theta = 1/2\).

\textbf{Remark 3.16e (Hessian Positivity).} When \(\Phi\) is \(C^2\),
the mass gap condition is equivalent to: \[
\nabla^2 \Phi(x^*)|_{(T_{x^*}(G \cdot x^*))^\perp} \succ \lambda_{\text{gap}} \cdot I
\] i.e., \textbf{Hessian positivity orthogonal to symmetry directions}.
The Łojasiewicz formulation is more general: it applies even when
\(\Phi\) is not \(C^2\), or when the landscape has degenerate directions
beyond symmetries.

\begin{definition}[Log-Sobolev inequality]
In the probabilistic setting with invariant measure $\mu$ supported near $M$, we say a \textbf{log-Sobolev inequality (LSI)} holds with constant $\lambda_{\mathrm{LS}} > 0$ if for all smooth $f: X \to \mathbb{R}$ with $\int f^2 \, d\mu = 1$:
$$
\mathrm{Ent}_\mu(f^2) := \int f^2 \log f^2 \, d\mu \leq \frac{1}{2\lambda_{\mathrm{LS}}} \int |\nabla f|^2 \, d\mu.
$$
\end{definition}

\hypertarget{axiom-reg-regularity}{%
\subsection{Axiom Reg (Regularity)}\label{axiom-reg-regularity}}

\begin{axiom}[Reg (Regularity)]
The following regularity conditions hold:
\begin{enumerate}
\item \textbf{Semiflow continuity:} The map $(t, x) \mapsto S_t x$ is continuous on $\{(t, x) : 0 \leq t < T_*(x)\}$.
\item \textbf{Measurability:} The functionals $\Phi$, $\mathfrak{D}$, $c$, $\mathcal{R}$ are Borel measurable.
\item \textbf{Local boundedness:} On each energy sublevel $K_E$, the functionals $\mathfrak{D}$, $c$, $\mathcal{R}$ are locally bounded.
\item \textbf{Blow-up time semicontinuity:} The function $T_*: X \to (0, \infty]$ is lower semicontinuous:
$$
x_n \to x \implies T_*(x) \leq \liminf_{n \to \infty} T_*(x_n).
$$
\end{enumerate}
\end{axiom}

\textbf{Fallback.} Axiom Reg is a minimal technical assumption. When it
fails, the framework does not apply---the system lacks the basic
regularity needed for a well-posed dynamical problem.

\textbf{Role in constraint class.} Axiom Reg provides the minimal
regularity infrastructure for the framework to function. It ensures that
trajectories are well-defined, functionals are measurable, and blow-up
times behave semicontinuously. These are not deep constraints but basic
requirements for the category-theoretic formulation.

\hypertarget{axiom-interdependencies}{%
\section{Axiom interdependencies}\label{axiom-interdependencies}}

The axioms are not independent. The relationships are:

\begin{proposition}[Implications]
The following implications hold between axiom combinations:
\begin{enumerate}
\item (D) + (Reg) $\implies$ sublevel sets are forward-invariant up to drift.
\item (C) + (D) + (Reg) $\implies$ existence of limit points along trajectories.
\item (C) + (D) + (LS) + (Reg) $\implies$ convergence to $M$ for bounded trajectories.
\item (Rec) + (Cap) $\implies$ quantitative control on time in bad regions.
\item (D) + (SC) $\implies$ Property GN (Generic Normalization) holds as a theorem, not an axiom.
\item (D) + (LS) + (GC) $\implies$ The Lyapunov functional $\mathcal{L}$ is explicitly reconstructible from dissipation data alone.
\end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}

Here (GC) is Axiom GC (Gradient Consistency), which applies to gradient
flow systems and enables explicit reconstruction of the Lyapunov
functional via the Jacobi metric or Hamilton--Jacobi equation.

\begin{proposition}[Minimal axiom sets]
The main theorems require the following minimal axiom combinations:
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Structural Resolution Theorem:} (C), (D), (Reg)
\item \textbf{GN as Metatheorem:} (D), (SC)
\item \textbf{Type II Exclusion Theorem:} (D), (SC)
\item \textbf{Capacity Barrier Theorem:} (Cap), (BG)
\item \textbf{Topological Suppression Theorem:} (TB), (LSI)
\item \textbf{Dichotomy Theorem:} (D), (R), (Cap)
\item \textbf{Canonical Lyapunov Theorem:} (C), (D), (R), (LS), (Reg)
\item \textbf{Action Reconstruction Theorem:} (D), (LS), (GC)
\item \textbf{Hamilton–Jacobi Generator Theorem:} (D), (LS), (GC)
\end{itemize}
\end{proposition}

Here (BG) is the Background Geometry axiom (providing geometric
structure via Hausdorff measure), (LSI) is the Log-Sobolev Inequality,
and (GC) is Gradient Consistency.

\begin{proposition}[The mode classification]
The Structural Resolution Theorem classifies trajectories based on which condition fails:
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{C fails} (No concentration) $\to$ Mode D.D: \textbf{Dispersion (Global existence)}---Energy disperses, no singularity forms, solution scatters globally.
\item \textbf{D fails} (Energy unbounded) $\to$ Mode C.E: \textbf{Energy blow-up}---Energy grows without bound as $t \nearrow T_*(x)$.
\item \textbf{Rec fails} (No recovery) $\to$ Mode C.E: \textbf{Energy blow-up}---Trajectory drifts indefinitely in bad region.
\item \textbf{SC fails} (Scaling permit denied) $\to$ Mode S.E: \textbf{Supercritical impossible}---Scaling exponents violate $\alpha > \beta$; blow-up contradicted.
\item \textbf{Cap fails} (Capacity permit denied) $\to$ Mode C.D: \textbf{Geometric collapse impossible}---Concentration on capacity-zero sets contradicted.
\item \textbf{TB fails} (Topological permit denied) $\to$ Mode T.E: \textbf{Topological obstruction}---Background invariants block the singularity.
\item \textbf{LS fails} (Stiffness permit denied) $\to$ Mode S.D: \textbf{Stiffness breakdown impossible}---Łojasiewicz inequality contradicts stagnation.
\item \textbf{GC fails} $\to$ Reconstruction theorems do not apply; abstract Lyapunov construction still valid.
\end{itemize}
\end{proposition}

\textbf{Remark 3.21 (Regularity via permit denial).} Global regularity
follows whenever:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Energy disperses (Mode D.D)---no singularity forms, or
\item
  Concentration occurs but a permit is denied---singularity is
  contradicted.
\end{enumerate}

When a local axiom fails, the resolution identifies which mode of
singular behavior occurs, providing a complete classification even for
trajectories that escape the ``good'' regime.

\textbf{Remark 3.22 (Constraint class organization).} The axioms are
organized into four constraint classes:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Conservation (D, Rec):} Thermodynamic balance---energy,
  dissipation, and recovery.
\item
  \textbf{Topology (TB, Cap):} Spatial structure---topological sectors
  and geometric capacity.
\item
  \textbf{Duality (C, SC):} Self-similar structure---compactness modulo
  symmetries and scaling balance.
\item
  \textbf{Symmetry (LS, Reg):} Local rigidity---stiffness near
  equilibria and minimal regularity.
\end{enumerate}

Each class addresses a different aspect of system behavior. Together,
they provide a complete classification of dynamical breakdown modes.

\hypertarget{part-ii-the-diagnostic-engine}{%
\part{Part II: The Diagnostic
Engine}\label{part-ii-the-diagnostic-engine}}

\emph{The Taxonomy of Failure and the Logic of Stability.}

\hypertarget{chapter-4-the-taxonomy-of-failure-modes}{%
\chapter{Chapter 4: The Taxonomy of Failure
Modes}\label{chapter-4-the-taxonomy-of-failure-modes}}

\hypertarget{the-structural-definition-of-singularity}{%
\section{The structural definition of
singularity}\label{the-structural-definition-of-singularity}}

In classical analysis, a singularity is often defined negatively---as a
point where regularity is lost. In the hypostructure framework, we
define it positively as a specific dynamical event where the trajectory
attempts to exit the admissible state space.

Let \(\mathcal{S} = (X, (S_t), \Phi, \mathfrak{D})\) be a structural
flow datum. Let \(u(t) = S_t x\) be a trajectory defined on a maximal
interval \([0, T_*)\).

\begin{definition}[Singularity]
A trajectory $u(t)$ exhibits a \textbf{singularity} at $T_* < \infty$ if it cannot be extended beyond $T_*$ within the topology of $X$, despite satisfying the energy constraint $\Phi(u(0)) < \infty$.
\end{definition}

The central thesis of this framework is that singularities are not
random chaotic events, but are \textbf{isomorphic to the failure of
specific structural axioms}. The axioms form a diagnostic system. By
determining exactly \emph{which} axiom fails along a singular sequence,
we classify the breakdown into one of fifteen mutually exclusive modes.

\textbf{The Fixed-Point Principle.} The axioms are not arbitrary choices
but manifestations of a single organizing principle:
\textbf{self-consistency under evolution}. A system satisfies the
hypostructure axioms if and only if its persistent states are fixed
points of the evolution operator: \(F(x) = x\). Singularities represent
states where \(F(x) \neq x\) in the limit---the evolution attempts to
produce a state incompatible with its own definition.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{the-taxonomy-of-failure-modes}{%
\section{The taxonomy of failure
modes}\label{the-taxonomy-of-failure-modes}}

The fifteen failure modes decompose according to four fundamental
constraint classes, each enforcing a distinct aspect of
self-consistency. This decomposition reflects the mathematical structure
of the obstruction space.

\begin{definition}[Constraint classification]
The structural constraints divide into four orthogonal classes:
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|}
\hline
\textbf{Class} & \textbf{Enforces} & \textbf{Axioms} \\
\hline
\textbf{Conservation} & Magnitude bounds & D, R, Cap \\
\textbf{Topology} & Connectivity & TB, Cap \\
\textbf{Duality} & Perspective coherence & C, SC \\
\textbf{Symmetry} & Cost structure & SC, LS, GC \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\end{definition}

Each class admits three failure types: \textbf{Excess} (too much
structure), \textbf{Deficiency} (too little structure), and
\textbf{Complexity} (bounded but inaccessible structure). For open
systems coupled to an environment, three additional \textbf{Boundary}
failure modes emerge.

\textbf{Table 4.3 (The Taxonomy of Failure Modes).}

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|}
\hline
\textbf{Constraint} & \textbf{Excess} & \textbf{Deficiency} & \textbf{Complexity} \\
\hline
\textbf{Conservation} & Mode C.E: Energy blow-up & Mode C.D: Collapse & Mode C.C: Event accumulation \\
\textbf{Topology} & Mode T.E: Metastasis & Mode T.D: Glassy freeze & Mode T.C: Labyrinthine \\
\textbf{Duality} & Mode D.E: Oscillatory & Mode D.D: Dispersion & Mode D.C: Semantic horizon \\
\textbf{Symmetry} & Mode S.E: Supercritical & Mode S.D: Stiffness breakdown & Mode S.C: Parameter instability \\
\textbf{Boundary} & Mode B.E: Injection & Mode B.D: Starvation & Mode B.C: Misalignment \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

\begin{metatheorem}[Completeness]
The fifteen modes form a complete classification of dynamical failure. Every trajectory of a hypostructure (open or closed) either:
\end{metatheorem}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Exists globally and converges to the safe manifold \(M\), or
\item
  Exhibits exactly one of the failure modes 1--15.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{proof}
The four constraint classes are orthogonal by construction. Each class admits three failure types corresponding to the logical possibilities for constraint violation. The boundary class adds three modes for open systems. The $4 \times 3 + 3 = 15$ modes exhaust the logical space.
\end{proof}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{diagnosis-of-genuine-singularities-sieve-calibration}{%
\section{Diagnosis of Genuine Singularities (Sieve
Calibration)}\label{diagnosis-of-genuine-singularities-sieve-calibration}}

A natural skeptical question arises: \emph{Does this framework ever
predict a singularity correctly, or does it define them away?} This
section demonstrates that the Sieve is a \textbf{discriminator}, not a
rubber stamp for regularity. We verify that the framework correctly
identifies systems known to form singularities by showing which axioms
fail.

\begin{metatheorem}[Sieve Discrimination]
The hypostructure Sieve is falsifiable: there exist physically meaningful dynamical systems for which the Sieve correctly predicts singularity formation by identifying axiom violations.
\end{metatheorem}

\begin{proof}
We exhibit three canonical examples where the Sieve correctly diagnoses singularities.

\textbf{Example 3.3.1: Euler Equations (Inviscid Fluids)}


Consider the incompressible Euler equations in $\mathbb{R}^3$:
$$
\partial_t u + (u \cdot \nabla)u = -\nabla p, \quad \nabla \cdot u = 0, \quad \nu = 0.
$$

\textbf{Hypostructure data:}
\begin{itemize}
\item State space: $X = L^2_\sigma(\mathbb{R}^3)$ (divergence-free vector fields)
\item Height functional: $\Phi(u) = \frac{1}{2}\|u\|_{L^2}^2$ (kinetic energy)
\item Dissipation functional: $\mathfrak{D}(u) = \nu\|\nabla u\|_{L^2}^2 = 0$ (no viscosity)
\end{itemize}

\textbf{Axiom Check:} Axiom D requires $\mathfrak{D} > 0$ for energy decay. Here $\mathfrak{D} \equiv 0$.

\textbf{Sieve Verdict:} Axiom D is \textbf{violated}. Mode C.E (Energy accumulation) or Mode D.D (Dispersion without dissipation) is permitted. The Sieve \textbf{does not predict regularity}.

\textbf{Reality:} Elgindi [@Elgindi21] proved finite-time singularity formation for smooth solutions to Euler in $\mathbb{R}^3$. The framework correctly identifies the missing dissipative mechanism.

\textbf{Example 3.3.2: Supercritical Nonlinear Schrödinger Equation}


Consider the focusing NLS in dimension $d \geq 3$ with cubic nonlinearity:
$$
i\partial_t \psi + \Delta \psi + |\psi|^2 \psi = 0.
$$

\textbf{Hypostructure data:}
\begin{itemize}
\item State space: $X = H^1(\mathbb{R}^d)$
\item Height functional: $\Phi(\psi) = \|\nabla \psi\|_{L^2}^2$ (gradient energy)
\item Scaling exponents: $\alpha = d/2 - 1$, $\beta = 2$ (from dimensional analysis)
\end{itemize}

\textbf{Axiom Check:} Axiom SC requires $\alpha > \beta$ (subcritical). For $d = 3$: $\alpha = 1/2 < 2 = \beta$ (\textbf{supercritical}).

\textbf{Sieve Verdict:} Axiom SC is \textbf{violated}. Mode S.E (Supercritical Cascade) is permitted. The Sieve \textbf{does not predict regularity}.

\textbf{Reality:} Supercritical focusing NLS is known to exhibit finite-time blow-up [@Sulem99]. Energy can concentrate without infinite dissipation cost. The framework correctly identifies the scaling obstruction.

\textbf{Example 3.3.3: Ricci Flow in Dimension 4}


Consider Ricci flow on a compact 4-manifold:
$$
\partial_t g = -2\text{Ric}(g).
$$

\textbf{Hypostructure data:}
\begin{itemize}
\item State space: $X = \text{Met}(M^4)/\text{Diff}(M^4)$ (metrics modulo diffeomorphisms)
\item Height functional: $\Phi(g) = \int_M |Rm|^2 \, dV_g$ (curvature energy)
\item Capacity constraint: Singularities must have codimension $\geq 4$ for surgical removal
\end{itemize}

\textbf{Axiom Check:} Axiom Cap requires singular sets to have sufficiently high codimension. In 4D, singularities can form on codimension-2 sets (surfaces, filaments).

\textbf{Sieve Verdict:} Axiom Cap is \textbf{violated} (capacity bound fails). Mode T.E (Topological Metastasis) is possible. The Sieve \textbf{does not predict regularity}.

\textbf{Reality:} 4D Ricci flow can form singularities along 2-dimensional surfaces that cannot be surgically resolved [@Hamilton97]. Unlike 3D (where Perelman's surgery works), 4D lacks the capacity margin. The framework correctly identifies the dimensional obstruction.

\textbf{Conclusion.} The Sieve has \textbf{teeth}: it correctly predicts singularity formation in all three canonical examples by identifying the specific axiom that fails. This demonstrates that regularity predictions are non-trivial—they depend on verifiable structural properties.
\end{proof}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{conservation-failures-modes-c.e-c.d-c.c}{%
\section{Conservation failures (Modes C.E, C.D,
C.C)}\label{conservation-failures-modes-c.e-c.d-c.c}}

\textbf{Conservation constraints enforce information invariance:} phase
space volume is preserved under reversible evolution, and total
information content is bounded. Violations occur when magnitudes escape
their permitted bounds.

\hypertarget{mode-c.e-energy-blow-up}{%
\subsection{Mode C.E: Energy blow-up}\label{mode-c.e-energy-blow-up}}

\textbf{Axiom Violated:} \textbf{(D) Dissipation}

\textbf{Diagnostic Test:} \[
\limsup_{t \nearrow T_*} \Phi(u(t)) = \infty
\]

\textbf{Structural Mechanism:} The dissipative power \(\mathfrak{D}\) is
insufficient to counteract the drift or forcing terms in the energy
inequality. The trajectory escapes every compact sublevel set \(K_E\).
The system exits the state space because the height functional becomes
infinite.

\textbf{Status:} The singularity is detected purely by scalar estimates;
no geometric analysis of the state \(u(t)\) is required. This is a
\textbf{genuine singularity}.

\textbf{Remark 4.5 (Mode C.E is the universal energy catch-all).} If
\(\limsup_{t \to T_*} \Phi(u(t)) = \infty\), the trajectory is
classified as \textbf{Mode C.E}, regardless of the mechanism: - Energy
