\hypertarget{completeness-of-the-failure-taxonomy}{%
\section{Completeness of the failure
taxonomy}\label{completeness-of-the-failure-taxonomy}}

The original six modes classify failures of the core axioms. The
four-constraint structure reveals additional failure modes corresponding
to the ``complexity'' dimension---failures where quantities remain
bounded but become computationally or semantically inaccessible.

\begin{definition}[Complexity failure]
A trajectory exhibits a \textbf{complexity failure} if:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Energy remains bounded: $\sup_{t < T_*} \Phi(u(t)) < \infty$.
\item No geometric concentration occurs: Axiom Cap is satisfied.
\item The trajectory becomes \textbf{inaccessible}: either topologically intricate (Mode T.C), semantically scrambled (Mode D.C), or causally dense (Mode C.C).
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

We now complete the taxonomy with all fifteen modes.

\hypertarget{the-complete-classification}{%
\subsection{The complete
classification}\label{the-complete-classification}}

\textbf{Mode C.E (Energy blow-up):} Violation of Conservation (excess).
\(\sup_{t < T_*} \Phi(u(t)) = \infty\).

\textbf{Mode D.D (Dispersion):} Violation of Duality (deficiency).
Energy disperses to infinity; global existence with no concentration.

\textbf{Mode S.E (Supercritical blow-up):} Violation of Symmetry
(excess). Self-similar blow-up with \(\alpha \leq \beta\).

\textbf{Mode C.D (Geometric collapse):} Violation of Conservation
(deficiency). Singular set has zero capacity.

\textbf{Mode T.E (Metastasis):} Violation of Topology (excess).
Topological sector change; action barrier crossed.

\textbf{Mode S.D (Stiffness breakdown):} Violation of Symmetry
(deficiency). Łojasiewicz exponent vanishes near \(M\).

\textbf{Mode D.E (Oscillatory singularity):} Violation of Duality
(excess). Frequency blow-up:
\(\limsup_{t \nearrow T_*} \|\partial_t u(t)\| = \infty\) while energy
remains bounded.

\textbf{Mode T.D (Glassy freeze):} Violation of Topology (deficiency).
Trajectory trapped in metastable state with
\(\mathrm{dist}(x^*, M) > \delta > 0\).

\textbf{Mode C.C (Finite-time event accumulation):} Violation of
Conservation (complexity). Infinitely many discrete events in finite
time.

\textbf{Mode S.C (Parameter manifold instability):} Violation of
Symmetry (complexity). Discontinuous transition in structural parameters
\(\Theta\).

\textbf{Mode T.C (Labyrinthine singularity):} Violation of Topology
(complexity). Topological complexity diverges:
\(\limsup_{t \nearrow T_*} \sum_{k=0}^n b_k(u(t)) = \infty\).

\textbf{Mode D.C (Semantic horizon):} Violation of Duality (complexity).
Conditional Kolmogorov complexity diverges:
\(\lim_{t \nearrow T_*} K(u(t) \mid \mathcal{O}(t)) = \infty\).

\textbf{Mode B.E (Injection singularity):} Violation of boundary
(excess). External forcing exceeds dissipative capacity.

\textbf{Mode B.D (Starvation collapse):} Violation of boundary
(deficiency). Coupling to environment vanishes while \(u \notin M\).

\textbf{Mode B.C (Boundary-bulk incompatibility):} Violation of boundary
(complexity). Internal optimization orthogonal to external utility:
\(\langle \nabla \Phi(u), \nabla U(u) \rangle \leq 0\).

\begin{theorem}[Completeness]
The fifteen modes form a complete classification of dynamical failure. Every trajectory of a hypostructure (open or closed) either:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Exists globally and converges to the safe manifold $M$, or
\item Exhibits exactly one of the failure modes 1--15.
\end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
We establish completeness in five steps.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item[\textbf{Step 1}] \textbf{(Constraint class enumeration).} The hypostructure axioms impose four independent constraint classes:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item \textbf{Conservation (C):} Energy bounds via Axioms D and Cap
        \item \textbf{Topology (T):} Sector restrictions via Axiom TB
        \item \textbf{Duality (D):} Compactness and coherence via Axioms C and R
        \item \textbf{Symmetry (S):} Scaling and stiffness via Axioms SC and LS
    \end{itemize}
    For open systems, the \textbf{Boundary (B)} class adds coupling constraints via Axiom GC.

    \item[\textbf{Step 2}] \textbf{(Failure type trichotomy).} For each constraint class, failure occurs in exactly one of three mutually exclusive ways:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item \textbf{Excess:} The constrained quantity diverges to $+\infty$
        \item \textbf{Deficiency:} The constrained quantity degenerates to $0$ or a measure-zero set
        \item \textbf{Complexity:} The constrained quantity remains bounded but becomes algorithmically or topologically complex
    \end{itemize}
    This trichotomy is exhaustive: any failure must involve either too much, too little, or too complicated.

    \item[\textbf{Step 3}] \textbf{(Mode count).} Four closed-system classes $\times$ three failure types $= 12$ modes. Adding three boundary modes gives $12 + 3 = 15$ total modes.

    \item[\textbf{Step 4}] \textbf{(Mutual exclusivity).} Modes from the same constraint class cannot co-occur at the same singular time: Excess and Deficiency are logical opposites, and Complexity is defined as bounded-but-irregular (excluding both extremes).

    \item[\textbf{Step 5}] \textbf{(Completeness by Metatheorem 18.1).} By the Constraint Completeness Theorem (Metatheorem 18.1), ruling out all 15 modes forces the existence of a continuation. Therefore the 15 modes exhaust all obstruction possibilities.
\end{enumerate}
\end{proof}

\textbf{Table 14.22 (The taxonomy of failure modes).}

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|}
\hline
\textbf{Constraint} & \textbf{Excess} & \textbf{Deficiency} & \textbf{Complexity} \\
\hline
\textbf{Conservation} & Mode C.E: Energy blow-up & Mode C.D: Collapse & Mode C.C: Event accumulation \\
\textbf{Topology} & Mode T.E: Metastasis & Mode T.D: Glassy freeze & Mode T.C: Labyrinthine \\
\textbf{Duality} & Mode D.E: Oscillatory & Mode D.D: Dispersion & Mode D.C: Semantic horizon \\
\textbf{Symmetry} & Mode S.E: Supercritical & Mode S.D: Stiffness breakdown & Mode S.C: Parameter instability \\
\textbf{Boundary} & Mode B.E: Injection & Mode B.D: Starvation & Mode B.C: Misalignment \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

\begin{corollary}[Regularity criterion]
A trajectory achieves global regularity if and only if all fifteen modes are excluded by the algebraic permits derived from the hypostructure axioms.
\end{corollary}

\hypertarget{the-diagnostic-algorithm}{%
\section{The diagnostic algorithm}\label{the-diagnostic-algorithm}}

Given a new system, the meta-axiomatics provides a systematic diagnostic
procedure.

\textbf{Algorithm 15.24 (Hypostructure diagnosis).}

\emph{Input:} A dynamical system \((X, S_t, \Phi)\). \emph{Output:}
Classification of failure modes or proof of regularity.

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  \textbf{Conservation test:} Does energy remain bounded?
  (\(\limsup \Phi < \infty\))

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    NO \(\to\) Mode C.E (energy blow-up)
  \item
    YES \(\to\) Continue
  \end{itemize}
\item
  \textbf{Duality test:} Does energy concentrate? (Axiom C)

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    NO \(\to\) Mode D.D (dispersion/global existence)
  \item
    YES \(\to\) Continue
  \end{itemize}
\item
  \textbf{Symmetry test:} Is scaling subcritical? (\(\alpha > \beta\))

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    NO \(\to\) Mode S.E possible (supercritical)
  \item
    YES \(\to\) Mode S.E excluded
  \end{itemize}
\item
  \textbf{Topology test:} Is the topological sector accessible? (Axiom
  TB)

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    NO \(\to\) Mode T.E (topological obstruction)
  \item
    YES \(\to\) Continue
  \end{itemize}
\item
  \textbf{Conservation test (capacity):} Is the singular set
  positive-dimensional? (Axiom Cap)

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    NO \(\to\) Mode C.D (geometric collapse)
  \item
    YES \(\to\) Continue
  \end{itemize}
\item
  \textbf{Symmetry test (stiffness):} Does Łojasiewicz hold near \(M\)?
  (Axiom LS)

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    NO \(\to\) Mode S.D (stiffness breakdown)
  \item
    YES \(\to\) \textbf{Global regularity}
  \end{itemize}
\item
  \textbf{Complexity tests:} For remaining cases, check Modes D.E--D.C
  using the specialized enforcers.
\item
  \textbf{Boundary tests:} For open systems, check Modes B.E--B.C.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{theorem}[Completeness of diagnosis]
Algorithm 15.24 terminates in finite steps and produces a complete classification.
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
We establish completeness of the diagnostic algorithm in five steps.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item[\textbf{Step 1}] \textbf{(Well-ordering of tests).} The tests are arranged in a decision tree with finite depth:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Tests 1–6 form the primary cascade (6 binary decisions)
        \item Tests 7–8 are the auxiliary complexity and boundary checks
    \end{itemize}
    Each path through the tree has length at most 8.

    \item[\textbf{Step 2}] \textbf{(Determinism of each test).} Each test has a binary outcome (YES/NO) determined by:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item \textbf{Test 1 (C.E):} $\limsup \Phi(u(t)) < \infty$ vs $= \infty$
        \item \textbf{Test 2 (D.D):} Existence vs non-existence of convergent subsequence modulo $G$
        \item \textbf{Test 3 (S.E):} $\alpha > \beta$ vs $\alpha \leq \beta$
        \item \textbf{Test 4 (T.E):} Topological sector accessibility (Axiom TB satisfaction)
        \item \textbf{Test 5 (C.D):} Capacity of singular set $> 0$ vs $= 0$
        \item \textbf{Test 6 (S.D):} Łojasiewicz inequality holds vs fails near $M$
    \end{itemize}

    \item[\textbf{Step 3}] \textbf{(Leaf classification).} Every leaf of the decision tree is labeled with either:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item A specific failure mode (classification achieved), or
        \item "Global regularity" (all permits satisfied)
    \end{itemize}

    \item[\textbf{Step 4}] \textbf{(Termination).} Since the tree has finite depth and each test terminates (by decidability of the relevant axiom conditions), the algorithm terminates in finite time.

    \item[\textbf{Step 5}] \textbf{(Completeness).} By Theorem 15.21, every trajectory either converges to $M$ or exhibits one of the 15 modes. The algorithm exhaustively tests for each mode in logical order. No trajectory escapes classification.
\end{enumerate}
\end{proof}

The eighty-three metatheorems organize naturally according to which

A metatheorem is an \textbf{enforcer} for constraint class $\mathcal{C}$ if it provides a quantitative bound that excludes failure modes in class $\mathcal{C}$.
\end{definition}

The metatheorems distribute as follows:
\end{proposition}

\textbf{Conservation enforcers} (Modes C.E, C.D, C.C): -

Logical depth - Recursive Simulation Limit: Self-modeling bounds - Bode
Sensitivity integral: Control bandwidth

constraints - Gödel-Turing Censor: Self-reference exclusion -
Near-Decomposability: Block structure

Transmission: Phase space rigidity - Anamorphic Duality: Uncertainty
relations - Epistemic Horizon: Computational irreducibility - Semantic
Resolution: Descriptive complexity

\textbf{Symmetry enforcers} (Modes S.E, S.D, S.C): - Anomalous Gap:
Scale drift - Galois-Monodromy Lock: Algebraic invariance - Gauge-Fixing
Horizon: Gribov copies - Vacuum Nucleation barrier: Phase stability

\begin{theorem}[Barrier completeness]
For each of the fifteen failure modes, there exists at least one metatheorem that provides a quantitative barrier excluding that mode under appropriate structural conditions.
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
We establish barrier completeness in three steps.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item[\textbf{Step 1}] \textbf{(Explicit barrier assignment).} We exhibit an enforcing metatheorem for each mode:

    \begin{center}
    \begin{tabular}{lll}
    \hline
    Mode & Enforcing Barrier & Reference \\
    \hline
    C.E & Energy-Dissipation inequality & Theorem 5.24 \\
    C.D & Capacity-Dimension bound & Theorem 6.3 \\
    C.C & Zeno barrier / finite event count & Corollary 4.8 \\
    T.E & Action gap / topological barrier & Theorem 6.4 \\
    T.D & Near-decomposability principle & Theorem 9.202 \\
    T.C & O-minimal taming & Theorem 4.14 \\
    D.E & Frequency barrier & Theorem 4.20 \\
    D.D & (Global existence—not a failure) & — \\
    D.C & Epistemic horizon principle & Theorem 9.152 \\
    S.E & GN supercritical exclusion & Theorem 6.2 \\
    S.D & Łojasiewicz convergence & Theorem 4.27 \\
    S.C & Vacuum nucleation barrier & Theorem 9.150 \\
    B.E & Bode sensitivity integral & Theorem 9.19 \\
    B.D & Input stability barrier & Theorem 4.33 \\
    B.C & Boundary-bulk incompatibility & Theorem 4.38 \\

    \item[\textbf{Step 2}] \textbf{(Verification of exclusion).} For each mode-barrier pair:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item The barrier theorem provides a quantitative bound (threshold energy, capacity lower bound, action gap, etc.)
        \item When the bound is satisfied, the corresponding axiom holds
        \item Axiom satisfaction excludes the mode by definition

    \item[\textbf{Step 3}] \textbf{(Structural conditions).} The "appropriate structural conditions" are precisely the hypotheses of each barrier theorem—scaling exponent relations, compactness assumptions, Łojasiewicz parameters, etc. Different systems satisfy different subsets of these conditions.

\hypertarget{structural-universality-conjecture}{%
\section{Structural universality
conjecture}\label{structural-universality-conjecture}}

The meta-axiomatics organizes the hypostructure framework around four
constraint classes---Conservation, Topology, Duality, Symmetry---which
characterize the requirements for a system to satisfy \(F(x) = x\).

The fifteen failure modes classify the ways self-consistency can break.
The eighty-three metatheorems provide quantitative bounds that exclude
these failures.

This perspective organizes the theorems into a coherent structure. Each
concrete system can be analyzed by asking: \emph{Does this system
satisfy the hypostructure axioms?}

\textbf{Conjecture 15.29 (Structural universality).} Every well-posed
mathematical system admits a hypostructure in which the core theorems
hold. Ill-posedness is equivalent to unavoidable violation of one or
more constraint classes.

\textbf{Remark 15.30.} The conjecture asserts that ``well-posedness''
and ``hypostructure compatibility'' are synonymous. A system is
well-posed if and only if: 1. It admits a height functional \(\Phi\) and
dissipation \(\mathfrak{D}\) satisfying Axiom D 2. Local singularities
concentrate (Axiom C) or disperse (Mode D.D) 3. The four constraint
classes (Conservation, Topology, Duality, Symmetry) can be instantiated
4. The diagnostic algorithm terminates with either global regularity or
a classified failure mode

\textbf{Evidence for Conjecture 14.29:}

\textbf{PDEs:} Parabolic, hyperbolic, and dispersive equations all admit
natural hypostructures. Well-posedness results (Cauchy-Kowalevski,
energy methods, dispersive estimates) are instances of axiom
satisfaction.

\textbf{Stochastic processes:} Fokker-Planck equations, McKean-Vlasov
dynamics, and interacting particle systems instantiate the framework
with entropy as \(\Phi\) and Fisher information as \(\mathfrak{D}\).

\textbf{Discrete systems:} Lambda calculus, interaction nets, and term
rewriting systems exhibit strong normalization (global regularity)
precisely when the scaling permit is denied (cost per reduction exceeds
time compression).

\textbf{Optimization:} Gradient flows, proximal methods, and variational
inequalities satisfy the framework with objective functional as \(\Phi\)
and squared gradient norm as \(\mathfrak{D}\).

\textbf{Control theory:} Stabilization, optimal control, and robust
control problems instantiate the framework with Lyapunov functions as
\(\Phi\) and control effort as \(\mathfrak{D}\).

\textbf{Geometric flows:} Mean curvature flow, Ricci flow, and harmonic
map heat flow satisfy the axioms with geometric energy functionals and
natural dissipation structures.

\textbf{Quantum field theory:} Renormalization group flows, BRST
cohomology, and gauge fixing procedures correspond to axiom
instantiation in infinite-dimensional settings.

\begin{theorem}[Partial verification]
For every well-posed PDE problem in the classical sense (local existence, uniqueness, continuous dependence), there exists a hypostructure instantiation where:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Well-posedness implies Axioms C, D, Rec hold.
\item Global regularity is equivalent to denial of all failure mode permits.
\item Singularity formation corresponds to a classified mode.
\end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
We establish the hypostructure instantiation in five steps.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item[\textbf{Step 1}] \textbf{(Semiflow construction).} Let the PDE be $\partial_t u = F(u)$ on a Banach space $X$ (e.g., $H^s(\mathbb{R}^d)$ for dispersive equations, $L^2(\Omega)$ for parabolic equations). Local well-posedness in the sense of Hadamard [@Tao06] provides:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item \textit{Existence:} For each $u_0 \in X$, there exists a maximal time $T^*(u_0) \in (0, \infty]$ and a unique solution $u \in C([0, T^*); X)$ with $u(0) = u_0$.
        \item \textit{Uniqueness:} Solutions are unique in the class $C([0, T]; X)$.
        \item \textit{Continuous dependence:} The data-to-solution map $u_0 \mapsto u$ is continuous from $X$ to $C([0, T]; X)$ for any $T < T^*(u_0)$.
    \end{itemize}
    Define the semiflow $S_t: X \to X$ by $S_t(u_0) := u(t)$ for $t < T^*(u_0)$. In the $\infty$-categorical framework, $S_t = \exp(t \cdot \nabla)$ is parallel transport along the flat connection (Definition 2.2).

    \item[\textbf{Step 2}] \textbf{(Axiom C - Compactness).} Choose the state space topology such that bounded energy sets are precompact. For Sobolev spaces, the Rellich-Kondrachov embedding $H^s(\Omega) \hookrightarrow\hookrightarrow H^{s-\epsilon}(\Omega)$ (compact embedding for $\epsilon > 0$ on bounded domains) ensures that sublevel sets $\{u : \Phi(u) \leq E\}$ are precompact in the weaker topology. This verifies Axiom C: bounded sequences have convergent subsequences modulo the symmetry group.

    \item[\textbf{Step 3}] \textbf{(Axiom D - Dissipation).} Energy methods provide a Lyapunov functional $\Phi: X \to \mathbb{R}$ satisfying $\frac{d}{dt}\Phi(u(t)) \leq -\mathfrak{D}(u(t))$ for some non-negative dissipation functional $\mathfrak{D}$. Standard constructions include:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item \textit{Parabolic equations:} $\Phi(u) = \frac{1}{2}\|u\|_{H^1}^2$, $\mathfrak{D}(u) = \|\nabla u\|_{L^2}^2$
        \item \textit{Damped wave equations:} $\Phi(u, u_t) = \frac{1}{2}(\|u_t\|^2 + \|\nabla u\|^2)$, $\mathfrak{D} = \gamma\|u_t\|^2$
        \item \textit{Navier-Stokes:} $\Phi(u) = \frac{1}{2}\|u\|_{L^2}^2$, $\mathfrak{D}(u) = \nu\|\nabla u\|_{L^2}^2$
    \end{itemize}

    \item[\textbf{Step 4}] \textbf{(Scaling exponents).} The PDE's scaling symmetry determines the exponents $(\alpha, \beta)$. If $u_\lambda(x, t) = \lambda^\alpha u(\lambda x, \lambda^\beta t)$ solves the equation whenever $u$ does, and the energy scales as $\Phi(u_\lambda) = \lambda^{s_c}\Phi(u)$, then the criticality exponent is $s_c = d\alpha/2 - \beta$ (where $d$ is spatial dimension). The classification is:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item \textit{Subcritical:} $s_c > 0$ (energy decreases under rescaling to small scales)
        \item \textit{Critical:} $s_c = 0$ (energy scale-invariant)
        \item \textit{Supercritical:} $s_c < 0$ (energy increases under rescaling to small scales)
    \end{itemize}

    \item[\textbf{Step 5}] \textbf{(Permit correspondence).} Classical regularity criteria from the PDE literature map bijectively to permit conditions in the hypostructure formulation:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Prodi-Serrin criteria ($u \in L^p_t L^q_x$ with $2/p + d/q = 1$) $\leftrightarrow$ Axiom SC (subcritical scaling)
        \item Beale-Kato-Majda criterion ($\int_0^T \|\omega\|_{L^\infty} dt < \infty$) $\leftrightarrow$ Axiom D with vorticity-based dissipation
        \item Constantin-Fefferman geometric condition $\leftrightarrow$ Axiom TB (topological/geometric barrier)
    \end{itemize}
    Denial of the corresponding permit (i.e., verification that the criterion holds) implies global regularity via the barrier mechanism.
\end{enumerate}
\end{proof}

\hypertarget{research-directions}{%

The structural universality conjecture suggests several extensions:

\textbf{Problem 1 (Mean curvature flow singularities).} Complete the
classification of singularities in mean curvature flow via the
hypostructure framework. Specifically: - Verify that Huisken's
monotonicity formula instantiates Axiom D with the Gaussian density as

singularities - Determine whether all singularity models are
self-shrinkers (Mode S.E excluded)

entropy functionals to higher-dimensional Ricci flow. Determine: -
Whether \(\mathcal{W}\)-entropy monotonicity extends beyond dimension 3
- The complete list of singularity models in dimensions 4 and higher -
Which constraint classes prevent formation of exotic singularities

\textbf{Problem 3 (Reaction-diffusion pattern formation).} Instantiate
the framework for Turing pattern formation in reaction-diffusion
systems: - Identify the Lyapunov functional governing pattern selection
- Classify instabilities as Conservation, Topology, Duality, or Symmetry
failures - Predict pattern wavelength from structural data alone

\textbf{Problem 4 (Neural network optimization).} Apply the
hypostructure framework to deep learning: - Identify loss landscape
geometry as a hypostructure with training dynamics as the flow -
Classify training failures (vanishing gradients, mode collapse,
overfitting) by constraint class - Determine which architectural choices
guarantee convergence (Axiom LS)

\textbf{Problem 5 (Turbulence and cascades).} Formulate energy cascades
as a hypostructure on scale-space: - The height functional should encode
energy at each scale - Kolmogorov scaling should emerge from Axiom SC -
Intermittency corrections should correspond to complexity-type failures

\textbf{Problem 6 (Biological morphogenesis).} Instantiate the framework
for developmental biology: - Model cell differentiation as dynamics on
Waddington's epigenetic landscape - Classify developmental abnormalities
by failure mode - Predict robustness of developmental programs from
structural data

\textbf{Problem 7 (Trainable discovery).} Implement the general loss
functional (Chapter 14) and train a neural system to discover
hypostructure instantiations for novel PDEs, automatically identifying
\(\Phi\), \(\mathfrak{D}\), symmetries, and sharp constants.

\textbf{Problem 8 (Algorithmic metatheorems).} Develop an algorithm
that, given a dynamical system specification, automatically: 1.
Constructs the diagnostic decision tree (Algorithm 15.24) 2. Identifies
which metatheorems apply 3. Computes the algebraic permit data 4.
Outputs either a regularity proof or a classified failure mode

\textbf{Problem 9 (Minimal surface regularity).} Complete the
hypostructure instantiation for area-minimizing currents: - Verify
Almgren's big regularity theorem via soft local exclusion - Classify
branch point singularities by constraint class - Extend to codimension
\textgreater{} 1 where singularities are unavoidable

\textbf{Problem 10 (Continuous universality).} Prove or disprove: every
continuous-time dynamical system with a smooth invariant measure admits
a hypostructure with \(\Phi\) given by (negative) entropy.

The preceding parts established the hypostructure framework: axioms,
failure modes, barriers, and instantiations. This part elevates the
framework from a classification system to a \textbf{complete
foundational theory} by proving that:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
