  The failure taxonomy is \textbf{complete} (no hidden modes)
\item
  The axiom system is \textbf{minimal} (each axiom is necessary)
\item
  The framework is \textbf{universal} (every well-posed system admits a
  hypostructure)
\item
  Hypostructures are \textbf{identifiable} (learnable from trajectories)
\end{enumerate}

This chapter establishes that the hypostructure axioms are both
necessary and sufficient for characterizing dynamical coherence.

\hypertarget{constraint-completeness-theorem}{%
\section{Constraint Completeness
Theorem}\label{constraint-completeness-theorem}}

The taxonomy of failure modes (Chapter 4) lists fifteen modes. The
following theorem proves this list is exhaustive.

\begin{metatheorem}[Constraint Completeness]
Let $\mathcal{H} = (X, S_t, \Phi, \mathfrak{D}, G, M, \ldots)$ be a hypostructure satisfying axioms D, R, C, SC, Cap, TB, LS, and GC.

Let $u: [0, T_*) \to X$ be a trajectory such that \textbf{no} admissible continuation exists beyond $T_*$ in any topology compatible with:
\begin{itemize}
\item the metric of $X$,
\item the scaling action of $G$,
\item the gauge-invariant completion from R,
\item and any of the dual topologies used in C.
\end{itemize}

Then \textbf{there exists at least one} failure mode $m \in \{\text{C.E, C.D, C.C, T.E, T.D, T.C, D.E, D.D, D.C, S.E, S.D, S.C, B.E, B.D, B.C}\}$ such that $u$ realizes $m$ at $T_*$.

Moreover:
\begin{enumerate}
\item \textbf{Maximality:} No other type of breakdown is possible.
\item \textbf{Locality:} If the failure occurs, the mode is constant on a subsequence approaching $T_*$.
\item \textbf{Orthogonality:} Modes from different constraint classes are mutually exclusive at any given singular time.
\end{enumerate}
\end{metatheorem}

\begin{proof}
We prove by contradiction. Assume no mode occurs at $T_*$. We show this implies $u$ admits a continuation, contradicting the hypothesis.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item[\textbf{Step 1}] \textbf{(Energy bounds from no C.E).} Since Mode C.E does not occur:
    $$\sup_{t < T_*} \Phi(u(t)) \leq E < \infty.$$
    By Axiom D, the trajectory has finite total cost $\mathcal{C}_{T_*}(u) < \infty$.

    \item[\textbf{Step 2}] \textbf{(Compactness from no D.D).} Since Mode D.D does not occur, energy does not disperse. By Axiom C, any sequence $u(t_n)$ with $t_n \nearrow T_*$ has a subsequence such that $g_{n_k} \cdot u(t_{n_k}) \to u_\infty$ for some $g_{n_k} \in G$ and $u_\infty \in X$.

    \item[\textbf{Step 3}] \textbf{(Subcritical scaling from no S.E).} Since Mode S.E does not occur, Axiom SC holds with $\alpha > \beta$. By Theorem 6.2 (GN from SC + D), any supercritical rescaling produces a profile with infinite dissipation cost, contradicting Step 1. Thus gauges $(g_{n_k})$ remain bounded.

    \item[\textbf{Step 4}] \textbf{(Geometric regularity from no C.D).} Since Mode C.D does not occur, Axiom Cap ensures the trajectory does not concentrate on zero-capacity sets. By Lemma 5.22, occupation time on thin sets is controlled.

    \item[\textbf{Step 5}] \textbf{(Topological triviality from no T.E, T.C).} Since Modes T.E and T.C do not occur, Axiom TB ensures the trajectory remains in the trivial topological sector with bounded complexity.

    \item[\textbf{Step 6}] \textbf{(Stiffness near $M$ from no S.D).} Since Mode S.D does not occur, Axiom LS holds near the safe manifold $M$. If $u_\infty \in U$ (the Łojasiewicz neighborhood), convergence to $M$ follows from Lemma 5.24.

    \item[\textbf{Step 7}] \textbf{(Gauge coherence from no B.C).} Since Mode B.C does not occur, Axiom GC ensures the normalized trajectory $\tilde{u}(t) = \Gamma(u(t)) \cdot u(t)$ has controlled gauge drift.

    \item[\textbf{Step 8}] \textbf{(Recovery from no C.C, T.D, D.E, D.C, S.C, B.E, B.D).} The remaining modes correspond to complexity-type failures (infinite events in finite time, glassy freeze, oscillatory blow-up, semantic scrambling, parameter manifold instability, injection/starvation). Their non-occurrence, combined with Steps 1–7, ensures:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Finite event count (no C.C)
        \item Escape from metastable states (no T.D)
        \item Bounded frequency content (no D.E)
        \item Bounded descriptive complexity (no D.C)
        \item Continuous parameter evolution (no S.C)
        \item Controlled boundary coupling (no B.E, B.D)
    \end{itemize}

    \item[\textbf{Step 9}] \textbf{(Extension construction).} By Steps 1–8, $u(t_n) \to g_\infty^{-1} \cdot u_\infty$ for some $g_\infty \in G$ with $u_\infty$ in the domain of the semiflow generator. By local well-posedness (Axiom Reg), there exists $\epsilon > 0$ such that $S_t(g_\infty^{-1} \cdot u_\infty)$ is defined for $t \in [0, \epsilon)$. Define:
    $$\tilde{u}(t) = \begin{cases} u(t) & t < T_* \\ S_{t - T_*}(g_\infty^{-1} \cdot u_\infty) & t \in [T_*, T_* + \epsilon) \end{cases}$$
    This is a valid continuation, contradicting the maximality of $T_*$.
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Conclusion:} At least one mode must occur.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}[Exhaustiveness of constraint classes]
The four constraint classes (Conservation, Topology, Duality, Symmetry) plus Boundary for open systems cover all possible failure mechanisms. Any new "failure mode" discovered must be a subcase of one of the fifteen.
\end{corollary}

\textbf{Key Insight:} The constraint classes are not a convenient
taxonomy but a \textbf{complete} partition of the obstruction space. The
proof shows that ruling out all fifteen modes forces the existence of a
continuation---the modes truly exhaust the ways dynamics can break.
\textbackslash end\{metatheorem\}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{failure-mode-decomposition-theorem}{%
\section{Failure-Mode Decomposition
Theorem}\label{failure-mode-decomposition-theorem}}

The structural dichotomy between \textbf{tame} (classifiable) and
\textbf{wild} (unclassifiable) mathematical objects is formalized by
Shelah's \textbf{Classification Theory} \autocite{Shelah90}. The failure
mode taxonomy reflects this dichotomy: tame failures (Modes 1-12) admit
finite-dimensional descriptions, while wild failures (Mode T.C) involve
infinite-dimensional pathology.

The following theorem shows that catastrophic trajectories decompose
into a countable union of atomic failure events.

\begin{metatheorem}[Failure Decomposition]
Let $u: [0, T_*) \to X$ be a finite-cost trajectory that does \textbf{not} converge to the safe manifold $M$.

Then there exists:
\begin{enumerate}
\item A finite or countable set of \textbf{singular times} $\{T_i\}_{i \in I}$ with $T_i \nearrow T_*$
\item A corresponding assignment of \textbf{failure modes} $m_i \in \{\text{C.E, ..., B.C}\}$ for each $i$
\end{enumerate}

such that:

\textbf{(1) Local factorization.} In some neighborhood $I_i = (T_i - \delta_i, T_i + \delta_i) \cap [0, T_*)$ of each singular time, the trajectory $u$ realizes mode $m_i$ in the sense of the local normal form theory (Chapter 7).

\textbf{(2) Completeness.} Outside $\bigcup_{i \in I} I_i$, the trajectory lies in the \textbf{tame region} where all axioms hold and no failure is imminent.

\textbf{(3) Orthogonality.} For distinct $i, j$ with overlapping neighborhoods, the modes $m_i$ and $m_j$ are from different constraint classes (Con, Top, Dual, Sym, Bdy).

\textbf{(4) Finiteness in finite time.} For any $T < T_*$, only finitely many singular times $T_i$ satisfy $T_i \leq T$.

\begin{proof}
We establish the decomposition in five steps.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item[\textbf{Step 1}] \textbf{(Localization via scaling).} Use the GN property (Theorem 6.2.1) to identify times where supercritical concentration occurs. At each such time, extract the local profile via Axiom C.

    \item[\textbf{Step 2}] \textbf{(Classification via permits).} For each extracted profile, test the algebraic permits (SC, Cap, TB, LS) to determine which fails. The first failing permit determines the mode.

    \item[\textbf{Step 3}] \textbf{(Finiteness from capacity).} By Axiom Cap, the total occupation time on high-capacity sets is bounded. This bounds the number of Mode C.D events. Similar arguments using D, TB, LS bound other mode counts.

    \item[\textbf{Step 4}] \textbf{(Orthogonality from constraint structure).} Modes from the same constraint class cannot co-occur at the same time because they represent alternative violations of the same axiom cluster.

    \item[\textbf{Step 5}] \textbf{(Tame region characterization).} Away from singular times, all axioms hold with uniform constants. Classical regularity theory applies.
\end{enumerate}
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}[No exotic singularities]
There are no "hybrid" or "mixed" singularities that combine mechanisms from the same constraint class. Every singular event is atomic.
\end{corollary}

\textbf{Key Insight:} Singularities are \textbf{spectral}—they decompose into orthogonal modes like eigenvectors. This is analogous to how a general linear operator decomposes into eigenspaces.
\end{metatheorem}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{axiom-minimality-theorem}{%
\section{Axiom Minimality Theorem}\label{axiom-minimality-theorem}}

The following theorem shows that each axiom is necessary: removing any
one allows a new failure mode to occur.

\begin{metatheorem}[Axiom Minimality]
For each axiom $A \in \{\text{D, R, C, SC, Cap, TB, LS, GC}\}$, there exists:
\begin{enumerate}
\item A hypostructure $\mathcal{H}_{\neg A}$ satisfying all axioms except $A$
\item A trajectory $u$ in $\mathcal{H}_{\neg A}$ that realizes the corresponding failure mode
\end{enumerate}

The mapping from missing axioms to realized modes is:
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{D (Dissipation) missing:} Backward heat equation $\to$ C.E (Energy blow-up)
\item \textbf{Rec (Recovery) missing:} Bistable system without noise $\to$ C.D (Collapse)
\item \textbf{C (Compactness) missing:} Free Schrödinger on $\mathbb{R}^d$ $\to$ D.D (Dispersion)
\item \textbf{SC (Scaling) missing:} Supercritical focusing NLS $\to$ S.E (Supercritical blow-up)
\item \textbf{Cap (Capacity) missing:} Vortex filament dynamics $\to$ C.D (Thin-set concentration)
\item \textbf{TB (Topology) missing:} Liquid crystal with defects $\to$ T.E (Metastasis)
\item \textbf{LS (Stiffness) missing:} Degenerate gradient flow $\to$ S.D (Stiffness breakdown)
\item \textbf{GC (Gauge) missing:} Yang-Mills without gauge fixing $\to$ B.C (Misalignment)
\end{itemize}

\begin{proof}
We construct each counterexample explicitly.

\textbf{Example 18.3.1 (D missing $\to$ C.E: Backward heat equation).}

Consider the backward heat equation on $\mathbb{R}^d$:
$$u_t = -\Delta u, \qquad u(0) = u_0 \in L^2(\mathbb{R}^d).$$

*Verification of other axioms:*
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{C (Compactness):} Bounded $L^2$ sequences have weakly convergent subsequences. $\checkmark$
\item \textbf{SC (Scaling):} The equation is scaling-invariant with appropriate exponents. $\checkmark$
\item \textbf{Cap, TB, LS, GC, R:} All hold vacuously or with standard constructions. $\checkmark$
\end{itemize}

*Failure of D:* The $L^2$ norm satisfies:
$$\frac{d}{dt}\|u\|_{L^2}^2 = 2\langle u_t, u \rangle = -2\langle \Delta u, u \rangle = 2\|\nabla u\|_{L^2}^2 > 0.$$
Energy \textbf{increases}, violating Axiom D.

*Result:* Generic smooth initial data leads to finite-time blow-up of the $L^2$ norm. This is Mode C.E (energy blow-up).

\textbf{Example 18.3.2 (C missing $\to$ D.D: Free Schrödinger equation).}

Consider the free Schrödinger equation on $\mathbb{R}^d$:
$$iu_t + \Delta u = 0, \qquad u(0) = u_0 \in H^1(\mathbb{R}^d).$$

*Verification of other axioms:*
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{D (Dissipation):} Energy $E(u) = \|\nabla u\|_{L^2}^2$ is conserved. $\checkmark$
\item \textbf{SC (Scaling):} The equation has scaling symmetry. $\checkmark$
\item \textbf{Cap, TB, LS, GC, R:} All hold. $\checkmark$
\end{itemize}

*Failure of C:* Consider a Gaussian wave packet $u_0(x) = e^{-|x|^2}$. The solution spreads as $t \to \infty$:
$$\|u(t)\|_{L^\infty} \sim t^{-d/2} \to 0.$$
Bounded energy does \textbf{not} imply precompactness in $L^2$—the mass disperses to infinity.

*Result:* The trajectory exists globally but does not concentrate. This is Mode D.D (dispersion/scattering). Note: D.D is \textbf{not} a singularity but global existence.

\textbf{Example 18.3.3 (SC missing $\to$ S.E: Supercritical focusing NLS).}

Consider the focusing nonlinear Schrödinger equation:
$$iu_t + \Delta u + |u|^{p-1}u = 0, \qquad p > 1 + \frac{4}{d}.$$

*Verification of other axioms:*
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{D:} Energy $E(u) = \frac{1}{2}\|\nabla u\|_{L^2}^2 - \frac{1}{p+1}\|u\|_{L^{p+1}}^{p+1}$ is conserved. $\checkmark$
\item \textbf{C:} Local compactness holds. $\checkmark$
\item \textbf{Cap, TB, LS, GC, R:} All hold. $\checkmark$
\end{itemize}

*Failure of SC:* In the supercritical regime $p > 1 + 4/d$, the scaling exponents satisfy $\alpha \leq \beta$. The subcritical condition fails.

*Result:* Self-similar blow-up solutions exist [Merle-Raphaël]. The profile $u(t,x) \sim (T_* - t)^{-1/(p-1)} Q((x - x_0)/(T_* - t)^{1/2})$ concentrates at finite time. This is Mode S.E (supercritical blow-up).

\textbf{Example 18.3.4 (LS missing $\to$ S.D: Degenerate gradient flow).}

Consider the gradient flow $\dot{x} = -\nabla V(x)$ on $\mathbb{R}^2$ where:
$$V(x) = |x|^{2+\epsilon} \sin\left(\frac{1}{|x|}\right), \qquad \epsilon > 0 \text{ small}.$$

*Verification of other axioms:*
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{D, C, SC, Cap, TB, GC, R:} All hold with the Lyapunov function $\Phi = V$. $\checkmark$
\end{itemize}

*Failure of LS:* Near the origin, $V$ oscillates infinitely. The Łojasiewicz exponent degenerates: for any $\theta \in (0,1)$, there exist points arbitrarily close to zero where:
$$|\nabla V(x)| < C|V(x) - V(0)|^{1-\theta}$$
fails.

*Result:* Trajectories spiral toward the origin but never reach it, spending infinite time oscillating. This is Mode S.D (stiffness breakdown).

\textbf{Example 18.3.5 (TB missing $\to$ T.E: Liquid crystal defects).}

Consider nematic liquid crystal dynamics with director field $\mathbf{n}: \Omega \to S^2$:
$$\partial_t \mathbf{n} = \Delta \mathbf{n} + |\nabla \mathbf{n}|^2 \mathbf{n}.$$

*Verification of other axioms:*
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{D:} The Oseen-Frank energy decreases. $\checkmark$
\item \textbf{C, SC, Cap, LS, GC, R:} All hold. $\checkmark$
\end{itemize}

*Failure of TB:* The topological degree $\deg(\mathbf{n}|_{\partial B_r}) \in \pi_2(S^2) \cong \mathbb{Z}$ is not preserved by the flow when defects nucleate. There is no action gap separating sectors.

*Result:* Hedgehog defects can nucleate or annihilate, changing the topological sector. This is Mode T.E (sector transition/topological obstruction).

\textbf{Example 18.3.6 (Cap missing $\to$ C.D: Vortex filaments).}

Consider 3D incompressible Euler equations with vortex filament initial data:
$$\omega_0 = \delta_\gamma \otimes \hat{\tau}$$
where $\gamma$ is a smooth curve and $\hat{\tau}$ its unit tangent.

*Verification of other axioms:*
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{D:} Energy (helicity) is conserved. $\checkmark$
\item \textbf{C, SC, LS, TB, GC, R:} All hold. $\checkmark$
\end{itemize}

*Failure of Cap:* The vorticity concentrates on a 1-dimensional set $\gamma(t)$ with zero 3-capacity. The singular set has codimension 2.

*Result:* The solution develops concentration on thin sets, potentially leading to finite-time blow-up via filament collapse. This is Mode C.D (geometric collapse).

\textbf{Example 18.3.7 (R missing $\to$ persistent metastability).}

Consider the double-well potential $V(x) = (x^2 - 1)^2$ with overdamped dynamics:
$$\dot{x} = -V'(x) = -4x(x^2 - 1).$$

*Verification of other axioms:*
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{D, C, SC, Cap, LS, TB, GC:} All hold. $\checkmark$
\end{itemize}

*Failure of Rec:* There is no recovery mechanism to escape the metastable well at $x = -1$ when initialized there. The "good region" $\mathcal{G}$ near the global minimum $x = +1$ is never reached.

*Result:* The trajectory dwells forever in the wrong well. Without noise or other recovery mechanism, escape is impossible. This represents effective collapse.

\textbf{Example 18.3.8 (GC missing $\to$ B.C: Yang-Mills without gauge fixing).}

Consider Yang-Mills theory with gauge group $SU(N)$:
$$D_\mu F^{\mu\nu} = 0, \qquad F_{\mu\nu} = \partial_\mu A_\nu - \partial_\nu A_\mu + [A_\mu, A_\nu].$$

*Verification of other axioms:*
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{D, C, SC, Cap, LS, TB, Rec:} All hold for the gauge-invariant quantities. $\checkmark$
\end{itemize}

*Failure of GC:* Without gauge fixing, the gauge orbit $\{g^{-1}Ag + g^{-1}dg : g \in \mathcal{G}\}$ is unconstrained. The effective theory drifts along gauge directions without physical meaning.

*Result:* The learned/predicted theory becomes misaligned with observable physics. This is Mode B.C (boundary-bulk incompatibility).
\end{proof}

\textbf{Key Insight:} The axioms are not overdetermined—each one prevents exactly the failure modes it is designed to prevent, and no other axiom can substitute. The framework is \textbf{minimal}.
\end{metatheorem}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

This chapter establishes that the hypostructure framework is not merely
a convenient language but the \textbf{natural} framework for a broad
class of dynamical systems, and that hypostructures can be learned from
observations.

\hypertarget{universality-representation-theorem}{%
\section{Universality Representation
Theorem}\label{universality-representation-theorem}}

\begin{metatheorem}[Universality of Hypostructures]
Let $S_t: X \to X$ be a semiflow on a separable metric space $(X, d)$ satisfying:

\textbf{(U1) Local well-posedness:} $S_t$ is continuous in $(t, x)$ and locally Lipschitz in $x$.

\textbf{(U2) Lyapunov structure:} There exists a lower-semicontinuous functional $E: X \to \mathbb{R} \cup \{+\infty\}$ such that $t \mapsto E(S_t x)$ is non-increasing for all $x$.

\textbf{(U3) Metric slope dissipation:} The metric slope
$$|\partial E|(x) := \limsup_{y \to x} \frac{[E(x) - E(y)]^+}{d(x, y)}$$
is finite $E$-a.e., and the dissipation identity holds:
$$E(S_t x) - E(S_s x) = -\int_s^t |\partial E|(S_\tau x)^2 \, d\tau, \qquad s < t.$$

\textbf{(U4) Natural scaling:} There exists a (possibly trivial) scaling action $(\mathcal{S}_\lambda)_{\lambda > 0}$ on $X$ that commutes with $S_t$ up to time reparametrization.

\textbf{(U5) Conditional compactness:} For each $E_0 < \infty$, the sublevel set $\{E \leq E_0\}$ is precompact modulo the symmetry group $G$ generated by $(\mathcal{S}_\lambda)$ and any additional isometries.

Then there exists a hypostructure $\mathcal{H} = (X, S_t, \Phi, \mathfrak{D}, G, M, \ldots)$ such that:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\Phi = E$ (the Lyapunov functional becomes the height)
\item $\mathfrak{D}(x) = |\partial E|(x)^2$ (the squared metric slope becomes dissipation)
\item Axioms D, C, R, SC hold (possibly on a full-measure subset)
\item If additional structure is present (Łojasiewicz near minima, topological grading), Axioms LS and TB also hold
\end{enumerate}

\begin{proof}
We construct the hypostructure in eight steps.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item[\textbf{Step 1}] \textbf{(Height functional).} Set $\Phi := E$. By (U2), $\Phi(S_t x) \leq \Phi(x)$ for all $t \geq 0$, with equality only for equilibria.

    \item[\textbf{Step 2}] \textbf{(Dissipation functional).} Set $\mathfrak{D}(x) := |\partial E|(x)^2$. By (U3), the energy-dissipation identity holds:
    $$\Phi(x) - \Phi(S_T x) = \int_0^T \mathfrak{D}(S_t x) \, dt.$$
    This is Axiom D with $\alpha = 1$ and $C = 0$.

    \item[\textbf{Step 3}] \textbf{(Symmetry group).} Let $G$ be generated by $(\mathcal{S}_\lambda)$ and any isometries of $(X, d)$ that commute with $S_t$ and preserve $E$.

    \item[\textbf{Step 4}] \textbf{(Compactness modulo $G$).} By (U5), bounded-energy sequences have convergent subsequences modulo $G$. This is Axiom C.

    \item[\textbf{Step 5}] \textbf{(Scaling structure).} If $(\mathcal{S}_\lambda)$ is non-trivial, compute the scaling exponents:
    $$\mathfrak{D}(\mathcal{S}_\lambda \cdot x) = \lambda^\alpha \mathfrak{D}(x), \qquad dt' = \lambda^{-\beta} dt$$
    under the scaling. If $\alpha > \beta$, Axiom SC holds.

    \item[\textbf{Step 6}] \textbf{(Safe manifold).} Let $M := \{x \in X : \mathfrak{D}(x) = 0\} = \{x : |\partial E|(x) = 0\}$ be the set of critical points of $E$.

    \item[\textbf{Step 7}] \textbf{(Recovery).} Define the good region $\mathcal{G} := \{x : E(x) < E_{\text{saddle}}\}$ where $E_{\text{saddle}}$ is the lowest saddle energy. Standard Lyapunov arguments give Axiom Rec.

    \item[\textbf{Step 8}] \textbf{(Łojasiewicz structure).} If $E$ is analytic (or satisfies Kurdyka-Łojasiewicz), then near each critical point:
    $$|\partial E|(x) \geq c \cdot |E(x) - E(x_*)|^{1-\theta}$$
    for some $\theta \in (0,1)$. This is Axiom LS.
\end{enumerate}
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}[Gradient flows are hypostructural]
Every gradient flow on a Riemannian manifold with a proper, bounded-below energy functional admits a hypostructure instantiation.
\end{corollary}

\begin{corollary}[AGS flows are hypostructural]
Every gradient flow in the sense of Ambrosio-Gigli-Savaré on a complete metric space admits a hypostructure instantiation.
\end{corollary}

\textbf{Key Insight:} The hypostructure framework is not an artificial imposition but the \textbf{natural language} for dissipative dynamics. Any system with a Lyapunov functional and basic regularity automatically fits the framework.
\end{metatheorem}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{rg-functoriality-theorem}{%
\section{RG-Functoriality Theorem}\label{rg-functoriality-theorem}}

The rigorous foundations for renormalization in quantum field theory
were established by \textbf{Constructive QFT} \autocite{GlimmJaffe87},
proving that certain interacting field theories can be defined as
mathematical objects satisfying the Wightman axioms. The
RG-Functoriality theorem extends this framework to general
hypostructures.

\begin{definition}[Coarse-graining map]
A \textbf{coarse-graining} or \textbf{renormalization group (RG) map} is a transformation $R: \mathcal{H} \to \tilde{\mathcal{H}}$ between hypostructures satisfying:

\begin{enumerate}
\item \textbf{State space reduction:} $R: X \to \tilde{X}$ is a surjection (possibly many-to-one)
\item \textbf{Flow commutation:} $R(S_t x) = \tilde{S}_{c \cdot t}(Rx)$ for some scale factor $c > 0$
\item \textbf{Energy monotonicity:} $\tilde{\Phi}(Rx) \leq C \cdot \Phi(x)$ for some $C < \infty$
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

\begin{metatheorem}[RG-Functoriality]
Let $R: \mathcal{H} \to \tilde{\mathcal{H}}$ be a coarse-graining map. Then:

\textbf{(1) Functoriality.} The composition $R_1 \circ R_2$ of coarse-grainings is again a coarse-graining.

\textbf{(2) Failure monotonicity.} If failure mode $m$ is \textbf{forbidden} in $\tilde{\mathcal{H}}$ (the coarse-grained system), then $m$ was already forbidden in $\mathcal{H}$ (the fine-grained system).

\textbf{(3) Exponent flow.} The scaling exponents transform as:
$$\tilde{\alpha} = \alpha - \delta, \qquad \tilde{\beta} = \beta - \delta$$
for some $\delta$ depending on the coarse-graining dimension.

\textbf{(4) Barrier inheritance.} Sharp constants and barrier thresholds in $\tilde{\mathcal{H}}$ provide upper bounds for those in $\mathcal{H}$.

\begin{proof}
\textbf{(1) Functoriality.} Direct verification: $(R_1 \circ R_2)(S_t x) = R_1(R_2(S_t x)) = R_1(\tilde{S}_{c_2 t}(R_2 x)) = \hat{S}_{c_1 c_2 t}(R_1 R_2 x)$.

\textbf{(2) Failure monotonicity.} Suppose mode $m$ occurs in $\mathcal{H}$ at time $T_*$ for trajectory $u$. Consider $\tilde{u} := R \circ u$. By flow commutation, $\tilde{u}$ is a trajectory in $\tilde{\mathcal{H}}$. By energy monotonicity, $\tilde{\Phi}(\tilde{u}(t)) \leq C \Phi(u(t))$, so if $\Phi$ blows up, so does $\tilde{\Phi}$. If $u$ fails permit checks (SC, Cap, etc.), the coarse-grained trajectory $\tilde{u}$ inherits these failures or stronger versions.

\textbf{(3) Exponent flow.} Under RG, length scales as $\ell \to \ell / b$ for some $b > 1$. The dissipation and time scale as:
$$\mathfrak{D} \to b^{-\alpha} \mathfrak{D}, \qquad t \to b^\beta t.$$
The effective exponents in the coarse-grained theory are $\tilde{\alpha} = \alpha - \delta$ where $\delta$ depends on the scaling dimension of the coarse-graining.

\textbf{(4) Barrier inheritance.} If $\tilde{\mathcal{H}}$ has critical threshold $\tilde{E}^* = \tilde{\Phi}(\tilde{V})$ for some profile $\tilde{V}$, then any profile $V$ in $\mathcal{H}$ with $R(V) = \tilde{V}$ has $\Phi(V) \geq C^{-1} \tilde{\Phi}(\tilde{V})$. Thus $E^* \geq C^{-1} \tilde{E}^*$.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}[UV-complete regularity implies IR regularity]
If the UV-complete (microscopic) theory forbids a failure mode, the IR (macroscopic) effective theory also forbids it.
\end{corollary}

\textbf{Key Insight:} Regularity flows \textbf{downward} under coarse-graining. If singularities are impossible at the fundamental level, they remain impossible in effective descriptions. The RG respects the constraint structure.
\end{metatheorem}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{structural-identifiability-theorem}{%
\section{Structural Identifiability
Theorem}\label{structural-identifiability-theorem}}

\begin{definition}[Parametric hypostructure family]
A \textbf{parametric family} of hypostructures is a collection $\{\mathcal{H}_\Theta\}_{\Theta \in \Theta_{\text{adm}}}$ sharing:
\begin{itemize}
\item The same state space $X$
\item The same symmetry group $G$
\item The same safe manifold $M$
\end{itemize}
but varying in:
\begin{itemize}
\item Height functional $\Phi_\Theta$
\item Dissipation functional $\mathfrak{D}_\Theta$
\item Scaling exponents $(\alpha_\Theta, \beta_\Theta)$
\item Barrier constants
\end{itemize}
\end{definition}

\begin{metatheorem}[Structural Identifiability]
Let $\{\mathcal{H}_\Theta\}_{\Theta \in \Theta_{\text{adm}}}$ be a parametric family. Suppose:

\textbf{(I1) Persistent excitation:} Observed trajectories explore a full-measure subset of the accessible phase space.

\textbf{(I2) Lipschitz parameterization:} For almost every $x \in X$:
$$|\Phi_\Theta(x) - \Phi_{\Theta'}(x)| + |\mathfrak{D}_\Theta(x) - \mathfrak{D}_{\Theta'}(x)| \geq c \cdot |\Theta - \Theta'|$$
for some $c > 0$.

\textbf{(I3) Observable dissipation:} The dissipation $\mathfrak{D}(S_t x)$ can be measured (with noise) along trajectories.

Then:

\textbf{(1) Local uniqueness.} If parameters $\Theta$ fit all observed trajectories up to error $\varepsilon$, then:
$$|\Theta - \Theta_*| \leq C \cdot \varepsilon$$
where $\Theta_*$ is the true parameter.

\textbf{(2) Barrier convergence.} The learned barrier constants (critical thresholds, Łojasiewicz exponents, capacity bounds) converge to the true values as $\varepsilon \to 0$.

\textbf{(3) Mode prediction stability.} Predictions about which failure modes are forbidden become stable: if $|\Theta - \Theta_*| < \delta$, then the set of forbidden modes for $\mathcal{H}_\Theta$ equals that for $\mathcal{H}_{\Theta_*}$.

\begin{proof}
\textbf{(1)} By (I2), the map $\Theta \mapsto (\Phi_\Theta, \mathfrak{D}_\Theta)$ is locally injective. By (I1), trajectory data constrains $(\Phi, \mathfrak{D})$ on a full-measure set. The inverse function theorem gives local identifiability.

\textbf{(2)} Barrier constants are continuous functions of $(\Phi, \mathfrak{D})$ in appropriate topologies. Convergence in $(\Phi, \mathfrak{D})$ implies convergence in barriers.

\textbf{(3)} Failure mode permissions are determined by inequalities on exponents and constants. These are preserved under small perturbations.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}[Hypostructure learning is well-posed]
Given sufficient trajectory data and the constraint that the underlying dynamics satisfies the hypostructure axioms, there is a unique (up to symmetry) hypostructure consistent with the data. This is the structural analogue of \textbf{Valiant's PAC Learning [@Valiant84]}, extending Probably Approximately Correct learning to dynamical laws.
\end{corollary}

\textbf{Connection to General Loss (Chapter 14).} The identifiability theorem provides the theoretical foundation for the general loss: minimizing the axiom defect $\mathcal{R}_A(\Theta)$ over parameters $\Theta$ converges to the true hypostructure as data increases.

\textbf{Key Insight:} Hypostructures are \textbf{scientifically learnable}. An observer with access to trajectory data can recover the structural parameters, including all the barrier constants that determine which phenomena are forbidden.
\end{metatheorem}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{meta-axiom-architecture-the-slomega-hierarchy}{%
\section{\texorpdfstring{Meta-Axiom Architecture: The S/L/\(\Omega\)
Hierarchy}{Meta-Axiom Architecture: The S/L/\textbackslash Omega Hierarchy}}\label{meta-axiom-architecture-the-slomega-hierarchy}}

This section develops the full axiom architecture introduced
conceptually in Section 3.0. The hypostructure axioms organize into
\textbf{three layers of increasing abstraction}, each enabling
progressively more powerful machinery. For each axiom X, we distinguish
refinement levels (X.0, X.A, X.B, X.C) that correspond to the different
layers.

\hypertarget{the-three-layer-architecture}{%
\subsection{The Three-Layer
Architecture}\label{the-three-layer-architecture}}

The layers form a hierarchy where each subsumes the previous: \[
\text{S-Layer (Structural)} \;\subset\; \text{L-Layer (Learning)} \;\subset\; \Omega\text{-Layer (AGI Limit)}
\]

\textbf{Layer S (Structural):} Axioms X.0 for each X \(\in\) \{C, D, SC,
LS, Cap, TB, GC, R\}. These are the minimal formulations required for
Structural Resolution (Theorem 18.2.7) and basic failure mode
classification. With only the S-layer, the framework provides: -
Classification of all trajectory outcomes into failure modes - Barrier
theorems excluding impossible modes - Metatheorems 19.4.A--C (soft local
globalization, obstruction collapse, stiff pairings)

\textbf{Layer L (Learning):} Axioms X.A, X.B, X.C for each X, plus the
three learning axioms L1--L3. This layer enables: - Local-to-global
construction theorems 19.4.D--F - Meta-learning theorem 19.4.H -
Parametric realization 19.4.L - Adversarial search 19.4.M - Master
structural exclusion 19.4.N

\textbf{Layer \(\Omega\) (AGI Limit):} A single meta-hypothesis reducing
all L-axioms to universal structural approximation. Enables fully
automated structure discovery.

The refinement levels map to layers as follows:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|}
\hline
\textbf{Refinement} & \textbf{Layer} & \textbf{Enables} \\
\hline
X.0 & S & Structural Resolution, basic metatheorems \\
X.A & L (localizability) & Theorems 19.4.D–F (local-to-global) \\
X.B & L (parametric) & Theorems 19.4.H, 19.4.L–M (learning) \\
X.C & L (representability) & Metatheorem 19.4.N (master exclusion) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{s-layer-structural-axioms}{%
\subsection{S-Layer: Structural
Axioms}\label{s-layer-structural-axioms}}

The S-layer contains three components:

\textbf{S1 (Structural Admissibility).} A true hypostructure
\(\mathbb{H}^*\) exists satisfying X.0 for all core axioms. This is the
foundational assumption: the mathematical object under study has a valid
hypostructure representation.

\textbf{S2 (Axiom Rep).} Dictionary correspondence holds---the two
``sides'' of the problem (analytic/arithmetic, spectral/geometric, etc.)
are structurally equivalent. This is the conjecture-level assumption
that the framework reduces all problems to.

\textbf{S3 (Emergent Properties).} Global properties such as height
finiteness, subcritical scaling, and stiffness. These are
\textbf{derivable} when the L-layer holds, but must be \textbf{assumed}
at the S-layer only.

\textbf{What S-Layer Unlocks:} Metatheorems 19.4.A--C and Structural
Resolution. With S-axioms verified, every trajectory is classified and
impossible modes are excluded.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\textbf{S-Layer Axiom Specifications (X.0)}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{c-compactness-refinements}{%
\subsection{C (Compactness) ---
Refinements}\label{c-compactness-refinements}}

\textbf{C.0 (Structural Compactness).} For a hypostructure
\((X, \Phi)\), sublevel sets \(\{x \in X : \Phi(x) \leq B\}\) are
compact (topological) or finite (discrete), for all \(B > 0\).

\textbf{C.A (Local Compactness Decomposition).} There exist: - An index
set of localities \(V\), - Local metrics
\(\lambda_v: X \to [0, \infty)\) with weights \(w_v > 0\),

satisfying:

\textbf{(C.A1) Finite local support.} For each \(x \in X\), the set
\(\{v \in V : \lambda_v(x) > 0\}\) is finite, with cardinality bounded
by \(M < \infty\) uniformly.

\textbf{(C.A2) Local sublevel finiteness.} For any finite
\(S \subset V\) and \(B > 0\):
\[\{x \in X : \lambda_v(x) \leq B \text{ for all } v \in S\}\] is finite
(or compact).

\textbf{(C.A3) Global height via local data.} The global height
\(H(x) := \sum_{v \in V} w_v \lambda_v(x)\) satisfies:
\(\{x \in X : H(x) \leq B\}\) is compact/finite for all \(B > 0\).

\emph{Remark.} Conditions (C.A1)--(C.A3) are precisely the hypotheses
(D1)--(D5) of Metatheorem 19.4.D.

\textbf{C.B (Parametric Compactness).} Let \(\Theta\) be the parameter
space. We require:

\textbf{(C.B1)} The map \((\theta, x) \mapsto \Phi_\theta(x)\) is
continuous on \(\Theta \times X\).

\textbf{(C.B2)} For any finite sample \(\{x_i\} \subset X\) and bound
\(B > 0\), the set
\(\{\theta \in \Theta : \Phi_\theta(x_i) \leq B \text{ for all } i\}\)
is relatively compact in \(\Theta\) (or empty).

\textbf{C.C (Representability).} For any continuous local metrics
\(\lambda_v^*\) on a compact domain and any \(\varepsilon > 0\), there
exists \(\theta \in \Theta\) such that:
\[\sup_{x \in K} |\lambda_{v,\theta}(x) - \lambda_v^*(x)| < \varepsilon\]
for all \(v\) in a finite subset of \(V\).

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{d-dissipation-refinements}{%
\subsection{D (Dissipation) ---
Refinements}\label{d-dissipation-refinements}}

\textbf{D.0 (Structural Dissipation).} There exists a nonnegative
dissipation functional \(\mathfrak{D}: X \to [0, \infty)\) such that:
\[\Phi(x(t_2)) - \Phi(x(t_1)) \leq -\int_{t_1}^{t_2} \mathfrak{D}(x(t)) \, dt\]
for all \(t_2 \geq t_1\) along trajectories.

\textbf{D.A (Local Dissipation Decomposition).} There exist: - Index
sets \(\mathcal{I}(t)\) for each scale \(t\), - Local energy pieces
\(\phi_\alpha(t) \geq 0\) for \(\alpha \in \mathcal{I}(t)\),

satisfying:

\textbf{(D.A1) Energy decomposition.}
\(\Phi(t) = \sum_{\alpha \in \mathcal{I}(t)} \phi_\alpha(t)\).

\textbf{(D.A2) Local dissipation control.}
\(\mathfrak{D}(t) \leq C \sum_{\alpha \in \mathcal{I}(t)} \phi_\alpha(t)\)
for some \(C > 0\).

\textbf{(D.A3) Growth bounds.} There exists \(G: T \to [0, \infty)\)
such that: - \(|\mathcal{I}(t)| \leq C_1 G(t)\), -
\(\phi_\alpha(t) \leq C_2 G(t)\) for all \(\alpha \in \mathcal{I}(t)\).

\emph{Remark.} Conditions (D.A1)--(D.A3) are hypotheses (E1)--(E2) of
Metatheorem 19.4.E.

\textbf{D.B (Parametric Dissipation Regularity).} We require:

\textbf{(D.B1)} The maps \((\theta, t) \mapsto \phi_{\alpha,\theta}(t)\)
and \((\theta, t) \mapsto \mathfrak{D}_\theta(t)\) are continuous.

\textbf{(D.B2)} The growth function \((\theta, t) \mapsto G_\theta(t)\)
is continuous.

\textbf{(D.B3)} For weight functions \(w(t)\) with
\(\sum_t w(t) G(t)^2 < \infty\), the sum
\(\sum_t w(t) \mathfrak{D}_\theta(t)\) depends continuously on
\(\theta\).

\textbf{D.C (Subcriticality Representability).} The parametric class
\(\Theta\) can represent all continuous local decompositions
\(\phi_\alpha(t)\) on compact truncated intervals \([0, T]\), with
approximation error controllable uniformly.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{sc-scale-coherence-refinements}{%
\subsection{SC (Scale Coherence) ---
Refinements}\label{sc-scale-coherence-refinements}}

\textbf{SC.0 (Structural Scale Coherence).} The scaling exponents
\((\alpha, \beta)\) satisfy the subcritical condition \(\alpha > \beta\)
on relevant orbits, ensuring dissipation dominates time compression
under rescaling.

\textbf{SC.A (Local Scale Decomposition).} There exists a local scale
transfer function \(L: T \to \mathbb{R}\) such that:
\[\Phi(t_2) - \Phi(t_1) = \sum_{u=t_1}^{t_2-1} L(u) + o(1),\] where
\(L(u)\) is expressible in terms of local quantities \(\phi_\alpha(u)\)
satisfying the hypotheses of Metatheorem 19.4.E.

\textbf{SC.B (Parametric Scale Regularity).} The map
\((\theta, t_1, t_2) \mapsto \Phi_\theta(t_2) - \Phi_\theta(t_1)\) is
continuous, and the decomposition \(L_\theta(u)\) varies continuously
with \(\theta\).

\textbf{SC.C (Scale Representability).} The parametric family \(\Theta\)
can approximate any continuous scale transfer \(L(u)\) on compact
\(u\)-ranges, with the error term \(o(1)\) controllable.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{ls-local-stiffness-refinements}{%
\subsection{LS (Local Stiffness) ---
Refinements}\label{ls-local-stiffness-refinements}}

\textbf{LS.0 (Structural Stiffness).} The Lyapunov functional is
strictly convex or the pairing non-degenerate on the relevant subspace,
excluding nontrivial flat directions beyond the obstruction sector.

\textbf{LS.A (Pairing Non-degeneracy Decomposition).} We require:

\textbf{(LS.A1) Sector decomposition.}
\(X = X_{\mathrm{free}} \oplus X_{\mathrm{obs}} \oplus X_{\mathrm{rest}}\).

\textbf{(LS.A2) Non-degeneracy.} The pairing
\(\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle\) is non-degenerate on
\(X_{\mathrm{free}} \oplus X_{\mathrm{obs}}\) modulo known symmetries.

\textbf{(LS.A3) No hidden vanishing.} Any \(x \in X\) orthogonal to all
of \(X_{\mathrm{free}} \oplus X_{\mathrm{obs}}\) lies in
\(X_{\mathrm{obs}}\).

\textbf{LS.B (Local Duality Structure).} There exist local spaces
\(X_v\) and local pairings \(\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle_v\) with:

\textbf{(LS.B1) Local perfect duality.} Each
\(\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle_v\) is non-degenerate.

\textbf{(LS.B2) Exact local-to-global sequence.}
\[0 \to X \xrightarrow{\mathrm{loc}} \bigoplus_v X_v \xrightarrow{\Delta} Y\]
is exact.

\emph{Remark.} Conditions (LS.A) and (LS.B) are hypotheses (F1)--(F6) of
Metatheorem 19.4.F.

\textbf{LS.C (Parametric Duality Regularity).} The local maps
\(\mathrm{loc}_v\) and pairings \(\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle_v\) can
be encoded by parameters \(\theta\) preserving exactness and duality
algebraically, with continuous dependence on \(\theta\).

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{cap-capacity-refinements}{%
\subsection{Cap (Capacity) ---
Refinements}\label{cap-capacity-refinements}}

\textbf{Cap.0 (Structural Capacity).} The obstruction set
\(\mathcal{O}\) has bounded capacity: obstructions cannot concentrate on
arbitrarily small sets.

\textbf{Cap.A (Lyapunov Height on Obstructions).} There exists a global
obstruction height:
\[H_{\mathcal{O}}(x) := \sum_{v \in V} w_v \lambda_v(x)\] defined via
local metrics as in Metatheorem 19.4.D, satisfying:

\textbf{(Cap.A1) Finite sublevel sets.}
\(\{x \in \mathcal{O} : H_{\mathcal{O}}(x) \leq B\}\) is finite for all
\(B > 0\).

\textbf{(Cap.A2) Gap property.} \(H_{\mathcal{O}}(x) = 0\) if and only
if \(x = 0\).

\textbf{Cap.B (Subcritical Obstruction Accumulation).} Under towers or
deformations:
\[\sum_t w(t) \sum_{x \in \mathcal{O}_t} H_{\mathcal{O}}(x) < \infty\]
for appropriate weight \(w(t)\), enabling Metatheorem 19.4.B
(Obstruction Capacity Collapse).

\textbf{Cap.C (Obstruction Representability).} The local metrics
defining \(H_{\mathcal{O}}\) can be represented by \(\Theta\)-parametric
functions, with continuous dependence on \(\theta\) and controlled
approximation error.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{tb-topological-background-refinements}{%
\subsection{TB (Topological Background) ---
Refinements}\label{tb-topological-background-refinements}}

\textbf{TB.0 (Structural Topology).} The state space has well-behaved
topology (manifold, Hilbert space, etc.) and the semiflow is
topologically compatible.

\textbf{TB.A (Stable Local Topology).} The local decompositions used in
Theorems 19.4.D--F induce charts or coverings such that:

\textbf{(TB.A1)} All local spaces are topologically standard
(finite-dimensional vector spaces, Banach spaces).

\textbf{(TB.A2)} Global structure is recovered via gluing compatible
with hypostructure maps.

\textbf{TB.B (Parametric Topological Stability).} Under variations of
\(\theta\):

\textbf{(TB.B1)} The topological type of local spaces and maps is
constant.

\textbf{(TB.B2)} No pathological behavior (singularities, non-Hausdorff
limits) occurs in admissible regions.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{gc-gradient-consistency-refinements}{%
\subsection{GC (Gradient Consistency) ---
Refinements}\label{gc-gradient-consistency-refinements}}

\textbf{GC.0 (Structural Gradient Consistency).} The flow \(S_t\) is a
gradient flow (or generalized gradient flow) of \(\Phi\) with respect to
some metric structure.

\textbf{GC.A (Local Gradient Compatibility).} The local representations
of \(\Phi\) and \(\mathfrak{D}\) via \(\lambda_v\), \(\phi_\alpha\), and
local pairings \(\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle_v\) are consistent with
global gradient structure:

\textbf{(GC.A1)} Local gradients glue to global gradient.

\textbf{(GC.A2)} Local duality and dissipative structure align with the
pairing hypostructure.

\textbf{GC.B (Parametric Gradient Regularity).} The dependence of the
gradient on \(\theta\) is continuous, allowing differentiation or
approximation of \(\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}\) via gradient methods.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{r-recoverycorrespondence-refinements}{%
\subsection{R (Recovery/Correspondence) ---
Refinements}\label{r-recoverycorrespondence-refinements}}

\textbf{R.0 (Structural Correspondence).} There exists a dictionary
\(D\) connecting two structural ``sides'' such that: - Rep-valid: \(D\)
is an equivalence of T-structures. - Rep-breaking: \(D\) fails to be an
equivalence.

\textbf{R.A (Local Correspondence Decomposition).} The dictionary \(D\)
decomposes into:

\textbf{(R.A1) Local dictionaries.} Maps \(D_v\) acting on local data.

\textbf{(R.A2) Local R-invariants.} Quantities whose mismatch captures
R-violation.

\textbf{(R.A3) Scalar Rep-risk.} A functional
\(\mathcal{R}_R: \Theta \to [0, \infty)\) such that
\(\mathcal{R}_R(\theta) = 0\) iff Axiom Rep holds for
\(\mathbb{H}(\theta)\).

\textbf{R.B (Parametric Rep-risk Regularity).} The functional
\(\mathcal{R}_R(\theta)\) is:

\textbf{(R.B1) Continuous} on \(\Theta\).

\textbf{(R.B2) Coercive} in the sense that large R-violations cannot
coexist with arbitrarily small axiom-risk.

\textbf{R.C (Adversarial Decomposability).} The space \(\Theta\),
together with \(\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}\) and \(\mathcal{R}_R\),
admits:

\textbf{(R.C1)} Adversarial optimization capable of finding
parametrizations with prescribed axiom-fit and R-violation.

\textbf{(R.C2)} Construction of universal Rep-breaking patterns
\(\mathbb{H}_{\mathrm{bad}}^{(T)}\) from discovered Rep-breaking models.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{l-layer-learning-axioms}{%
\subsection{L-Layer: Learning Axioms}\label{l-layer-learning-axioms}}

The L-layer adds three axioms that enable the computational machinery.
When these hold, the S-layer's ``emergent properties'' (S3) become
\textbf{derivable theorems} rather than assumptions.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\begin{axiom}[L1 (Representational Completeness / Expressivity)]
A parametric family $\Theta$ is dense in the space of admissible hypostructures: for any $\mathbb{H}^*$ satisfying S1 and any $\varepsilon > 0$, there exists $\theta \in \Theta$ such that
$$\|\mathbb{H}(\theta) - \mathbb{H}^*\| < \varepsilon$$
in an appropriate topology on hypostructure space.
\end{axiom}

\emph{Theoretical justification:} Theorem 13.40 (Axiom-Expressivity). If
\(\Theta\) has the universal approximation property, then
\(\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\theta) \to 0\) implies
\(\mathbb{H}(\theta) \to \mathbb{H}^*\).

\emph{Implementation:} The X.C refinements for each axiom ensure L1
holds locally. Global L1 follows from gluing.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\begin{axiom}[L2 (Persistent Excitation / Data Coverage)]
The training distribution $\mu$ on trajectories distinguishes structures: for any two hypostructures $\mathbb{H}_1 \neq \mathbb{H}_2$ with $\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\mathbb{H}_1) = \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\mathbb{H}_2) = 0$,
$$\exists A \in \mathcal{A}: \quad \mathcal{R}_A(\mathbb{H}_1; \mu) \neq \mathcal{R}_A(\mathbb{H}_2; \mu).$$
\end{axiom}

\emph{Theoretical justification:} Remark 14.31 (Persistent Excitation).
The condition ensures identifiability from finite data---no two
genuinely different structures can produce identical defect signatures
across all axioms.

\emph{Implementation:} The X.B refinements provide the regularity needed
for continuous dependence on data.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\begin{axiom}[L3 (Non-Degenerate Parametrization / Identifiability)]
The map $\theta \mapsto \mathbb{H}(\theta)$ is locally Lipschitz and injective:
\end{axiom}

\textbf{(L3.1)} For all \(\theta_1, \theta_2\) in compact subsets of
\(\Theta\):
\[\|\mathbb{H}(\theta_1) - \mathbb{H}(\theta_2)\| \leq L \|\theta_1 - \theta_2\|.\]

\textbf{(L3.2)}
\(\mathbb{H}(\theta_1) = \mathbb{H}(\theta_2) \implies \theta_1 = \theta_2\)
(up to symmetry).

\emph{Theoretical justification:} Theorem 14.30 (Meta-Identifiability).
Under L3, gradient descent on \(\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}\)
converges to the correct parameters.

\emph{Implementation:} The X.B refinements impose the continuity
conditions; L3.2 excludes degenerate parametrizations.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\textbf{What L-Layer Enables: Derivability of S3 Properties}

When L1--L3 hold together with the X.A/B/C refinements, the emergent
properties (S3) become theorems:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|}
\hline
\textbf{S3 Property} & \textbf{Derived From} & \textbf{Via Theorem} \\
\hline
Global Height $H(x) < \infty$ & L1 (expressivity) + C.A & 19.4.D \\
Subcritical Scaling $\alpha > \beta$ & L1 + D.A/SC.A & 19.4.E \\
Stiffness (non-degeneracy) & L1 + LS.A/LS.B & 19.4.F \\
Global Coercivity & L3 (identifiability) & 14.30 \\
Convergence of $\theta_n \to \theta^*$ & L1 + L2 + L3 & 19.4.H \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

The logic: L1 ensures representability, L2 ensures distinguishability,
L3 ensures stability. Together they transform the S-layer's analytic
assumptions into consequences of the learning architecture.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\hypertarget{omega-layer-the-agi-limit}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{\(\Omega\)-Layer: The AGI
Limit}{\textbackslash Omega-Layer: The AGI Limit}}\label{omega-layer-the-agi-limit}}

The \(\Omega\)-layer is the theoretical limit of the framework. It
reduces all L-axioms to a single meta-hypothesis: \textbf{universal
structural approximation}.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\textbf{The Four Reductions}

Under stronger conditions, each L-axiom becomes unnecessary:

\textbf{1. S1 (Admissibility) \(\to\) Diagnostic.} The framework does
not assume regularity---it \emph{tests} for it. Theorem 15.21 (Failure
Mode Classification) shows that non-zero defects
\(\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\theta^*) > 0\) classify exactly which
axiom fails and which failure mode occurs. The hypostructure framework
is a diagnostic tool, not a regularity assumption.

\textbf{2. L2 (Excitation) \(\to\) Active Probing.} Theorem 13.44
(Active Probing) shows that an active learner can generate persistently
exciting data by targeted queries. Sample complexity for hypostructure
identification is: \[N = O\left(\frac{d \sigma^2}{\Delta^2}\right)\]
where \(d\) is the effective dimension, \(\sigma^2\) is noise variance,
and \(\Delta\) is the minimum gap between distinct structures. The
learner need not passively observe---it can actively probe.

\textbf{3. L3 (Identifiability) \(\to\) Singular Learning Theory.} Even
when \(\theta \mapsto \mathbb{H}(\theta)\) is degenerate (non-injective,
singular Hessian), Watanabe's Singular Learning Theory
\autocite{Watanabe09} shows that the \textbf{Real Log Canonical
Threshold (RLCT)} controls convergence:
\[\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\hat{\theta}_N)] = \frac{\lambda}{N} + o(1/N)\]
where \(\lambda\) is the RLCT, which is finite even at singularities.
Degeneracy slows convergence but does not prevent it.

\textbf{4. L1 (Expressivity) \(\to\) Hierarchical Approximation.}
Replace a fixed \(\Theta\) with a hierarchy of increasing expressivity:
\[\Theta_1 \subset \Theta_2 \subset \Theta_3 \subset \cdots, \quad \Theta = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty \Theta_n.\]
Universal approximation holds in the limit. Practical learning uses
\(\Theta_n\) for finite \(n\), accepting approximation error
\(\varepsilon_n \to 0\).

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\textbf{Axiom \(\Omega\) (AGI Limit \autocite{Hutter05})}

This axiom formalizes the limit of optimal inference, analogous to
Hutter's AIXI framework \autocite{Hutter05} as a computable
approximation to Solomonoff induction. Access to a learning agent
\(\mathcal{A}\) equipped with:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  \textbf{Universal Approximation:} \(\Theta = \bigcup_n \Theta_n\) is
  dense in continuous functionals on trajectory data.
\item
  \textbf{Optimal Experiment Design:} Ability to probe system \(S\) and
  observe trajectories \(\{u_i\}_{i=1}^N\) at chosen initial conditions.
\item
  \textbf{Defect Minimization:} An optimization oracle that, given data
  \(\{u_i\}\), returns
  \[\hat{\theta} = \arg\min_{\theta \in \Theta_n} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\theta; \{u_i\}).\]
\end{enumerate}

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\textbf{Hypothesis \(\Omega\) (Universal Structural Approximation)}

System \(S\) belongs to the closure of \textbf{computable
hypostructures}:
\[S \in \overline{\{\mathbb{H} : \mathbb{H} \text{ has finite description in (Energy, Dissipation, Symmetry, Topology)}\}}.\]

In other words, the physics of \(S\) is approximable by a finite
combination of: - Energy functionals \(\Phi\) - Dissipation structures
\(\mathfrak{D}\) - Symmetry groups \(G\) - Topological invariants
\(\mathcal{T}\)

This is the analog of the Church-Turing thesis for dynamical systems:
all physically realizable systems admit hypostructure descriptions.

\begin{center}\rule{0.5\linewidth}{0.5pt}\end{center}

\begin{metatheorem}[Convergence of Structure]
*Combining Theorems 13.44 (Active Probing), 13.40 (Axiom-Expressivity), and 15.25 (Defect-to-Mode).*

Let $\mathcal{A}$ be a AGI Limit (Axiom $\Omega$) applied to system $S$ satisfying Hypothesis $\Omega$. Let $\{\theta_n\}$ be the sequence of learned parameters with increasing data and model capacity. Then:

\textbf{(1) Regular case:} If $S$ admits a regular hypostructure (all S-axioms satisfied), then:
$$\theta_n \to \theta^*, \quad \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\theta_n) \to 0,$$
and $\mathbb{H}(\theta^*)$ satisfies all structural axioms.

\textbf{(2) Singular case:} If $S$ violates some S-axiom, then:
$$\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\theta^*) > 0,$$
and the non-zero defects form a \textbf{Response Signature} $(r_C, r_D, r_{SC}, r_{LS}, r_{Cap}, r_{TB}, r_{GC})$ classifying the failure mode.

\textbf{(3) Emergence of analyticity:} The analytic properties (global bounds, coercivity, stiffness) that the S-layer must assume become \textit{emergent properties of $\theta^*$}:
\begin{itemize}
\item If convergence occurs, these properties hold for $\mathbb{H}(\theta^*)$.
\item If convergence fails, the failure signature identifies which property is violated.
\end{itemize}

\begin{proof}
We establish each part in turn.

\textbf{Part (1) — Regular case:}

\begin{enumerate}
    \item[\textbf{Step 1a}] \textbf{(Risk convergence).} By Theorem 13.40 (Axiom-Expressivity), the parameterized family $\{\mathbb{H}(\theta)\}_{\theta \in \Theta}$ contains the true hypostructure $\mathbb{H}^*$ at some parameter $\theta^* \in \Theta$. The axiom risk functional:
    $$\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\theta) = \sum_{A \in \mathcal{A}} w_A \cdot d_A(\theta)^2$$
    where $d_A(\theta)$ measures the defect in axiom $A$, satisfies $\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\theta^*) = 0$ when all axioms hold.

    \item[\textbf{Step 1b}] \textbf{(Convergence rate via RLCT).} By Watanabe's Singular Learning Theory [@Watanabe09], the Bayesian posterior concentrates at rate:
    $$\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\theta_n)] = O\left(\frac{\lambda}{n}\right)$$
    where $\lambda$ is the real log canonical threshold (RLCT) of the loss function at $\theta^*$. For regular (non-degenerate) minimizers, $\lambda = d/2$ where $d = \dim(\Theta)$. For singular minimizers, $\lambda < d/2$, yielding faster convergence.

    \item[\textbf{Step 1c}] \textbf{(Structure recovery).} By Theorem 13.44 (Active Probing), with $T \gtrsim d\sigma^2/\Delta^2 \cdot \log(1/\delta)$ samples the estimator $\hat{\theta}_T$ satisfies $|\hat{\theta}_T - \theta^*| < \varepsilon$ with probability $\geq 1 - \delta$. The identified $\mathbb{H}(\hat{\theta}_T)$ satisfies all structural axioms up to $O(\varepsilon)$ error.
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Part (2) — Singular case:}

\begin{enumerate}
    \item[\textbf{Step 2a}] \textbf{(Non-zero defects).} If $S$ violates some S-axiom, then for all $\theta \in \Theta$: $\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\theta) > 0$. The minimizer $\theta^* = \arg\min_\theta \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\theta)$ achieves a strictly positive residual $\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\theta^*) > 0$.

    \item[\textbf{Step 2b}] \textbf{(Defect-to-mode bijection).} By Theorem 15.25, the non-zero defect vector $(d_C, d_D, d_{SC}, d_{LS}, d_{Cap}, d_{TB}, d_{GC}, d_R)$ at $\theta^*$ maps bijectively to the failure-mode taxonomy. Define the Response Signature:
    $$r_A := \frac{d_A(\theta^*)}{\max_{B \in \mathcal{A}} d_B(\theta^*)}$$
    This normalized vector is the minimal obstruction certificate, identifying which constraint class fails and with what relative severity.
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Part (3) — Emergence of analyticity:}

\begin{enumerate}
    \item[\textbf{Step 3a}] \textbf{(Local-to-global transfer).} When $\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\theta^*) = 0$, each axiom defect $d_A(\theta^*) = 0$ implies the corresponding local estimate holds for $\mathbb{H}(\theta^*)$:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item $d_C = 0 \Rightarrow$ sublevel sets $\{\Phi \leq E\}$ are precompact (Axiom C)
        \item $d_D = 0 \Rightarrow$ dissipation inequality $\dot{\Phi} \leq -\mathfrak{D}$ holds (Axiom D)
        \item $d_{SC} = 0 \Rightarrow$ subcritical scaling bounds apply (Axiom SC)
    \end{itemize}

    \item[\textbf{Step 3b}] \textbf{(Global properties via metatheorems).} Theorems 19.4.D–F establish that local axiom satisfaction propagates to global properties:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Theorem 19.4.D: Local compactness + dissipation $\Rightarrow$ existence of global attractor
        \item Theorem 19.4.E: Local scaling + capacity bounds $\Rightarrow$ global regularity
        \item Theorem 19.4.F: Local duality + stiffness $\Rightarrow$ structural stability under perturbation
    \end{itemize}

    \item[\textbf{Step 3c}] \textbf{(Failure localization).} When convergence fails ($\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{axioms}}(\theta^*) > 0$), the Response Signature identifies which global property is violated and predicts the corresponding failure mode from the taxonomy. The dominant defect component $\arg\max_A r_A$ localizes the primary obstruction.
\end{enumerate}
\end{proof}

---

\textbf{Remark (Watanabe's Singular Learning Theory).} Standard learning theory assumes non-degenerate Fisher information. In practice, neural network loss landscapes are highly singular—the Hessian has many zero eigenvalues. Watanabe's framework resolves this by replacing the number of parameters with the RLCT $\lambda$, which measures the "effective dimension" at a singularity:
$$\lambda = \inf\{r > 0 : \int_{\Theta} \mathcal{R}(\theta)^{-r} d\theta < \infty\}.$$
For regular models, $\lambda = d/2$ (half the parameter count). For singular models, $\lambda < d/2$—singularities help generalization. This explains why the framework converges even when L3 fails: the RLCT remains finite.

---
\end{metatheorem}

This section presents fourteen framework-level metatheorems that serve
as universal tools across all hypostructure instantiations. They are
formulated purely in terms of the axiom system and abstract structures
(towers, obstruction sectors, pairing sectors) without reference to any
specific problem domain. The metatheorems divide into five groups:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{19.4.A--C:} Local-to-global structure (tower globalization,
  obstruction collapse, stiff pairings)
\item

  subcriticality, duality, master schema, meta-learning)
\item
  \textbf{19.4.I--K:} Categorical obstruction machinery (morphisms,
  universal bad patterns, exclusion schema)
\item
  \textbf{19.4.L--M:} Computational layer (parametric realization,
  adversarial search for Rep-breaking patterns)
\item
  \textbf{19.4.N:} Master theorem (structural exclusion unifying all
  previous metatheorems)
\end{itemize}
